{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{See also|Taxation in the Republic of Ireland}} [[File:Charlie McCreevy portrait.jpg|thumb|'''Finance Min. [[Charlie McCreevy]]''' Reduced Irish corporate tax from 32% to 12.5% in the 1999 Finance Act, and whose 1997 Tax and Consolidation Act, laid the framework for Ireland's [[BEPS]] tax tools, the world's largest.]] '''Ireland's Corporate Tax System''' is a central component of Ireland's economy. In 2016–17, foreign firms paid 80% of Irish corporate tax, employed 25% of the Irish labour force (paid 50% of Irish salary tax), and created 57% of Irish OECD non-farm value-add. U.S.–controlled firms represent almost all foreign firms in Ireland and in 2017 were 25 of the top 50 Irish firms, and 70% of the revenue of the top 50 Irish firms ({{slink|#Low tax economy}}). By 2018, Ireland had received the most U.S. {{slink|#Corporate tax inversions}} in history, and Apple was over one–fifth of Irish GDP. Academics rank Ireland as the largest [[tax haven]]; larger than the Caribbean tax haven system.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/ireland/ireland-named-as-world-s-biggest-tax-haven-8tx2ngcgj|title=Ireland named as world’s biggest tax haven|publisher=The Times U.K.|date=14 June 2018|quote=Research conducted by academics at the University of California, Berkeley and the University of Copenhagen estimated that foreign multinationals moved €90 billion of profits to Ireland in 2015 — more than all Caribbean countries combined.}} [[File:Apple logo black.svg|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' Ireland's largest company, and over one-fifth of Irish GDP, whose [[Investigation of Apple's transfer pricing arrangements with Ireland|2016 EU €13 billion fine]] on their [[Double Irish]] BEPS scheme is the largest tax fine in history.]] Ireland's "headline" corporation tax rate is 12.5%, however, foreign multinationals pay an {{slink|#Effective tax rate (ETR)}} of under 4% on global profits "shifted" to Ireland, via Ireland's global network of bilateral [[tax treaties]]. These lower effective tax rates are achieved by a complex set of Irish [[base erosion and profit shifting]] ("BEPS") tools which handle the largest BEPS flows in the world (e.g. the '''[[Double Irish]]''' as used by Google and Facebook, the '''[[double Irish arrangement#Replacement by single malt|Single Malt]]''' as used by Microsoft and Allergan, and '''[[double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]''' as used by Accenture, and by Apple post Q1 2015). Ireland's main {{slink|#Multinational tax schemes}} use "[[intellectual property]]" ("IP") accounting to affect the [[BEPS]] movement, which is why almost all foreign multinationals in Ireland are from the industries with substantial IP, namely technology and life sciences. Multinationals from jurisdictions with "territorial tax" systems (i.e. almost all OECD countries), make little use of tax havens, thus, almost most foreign multinationals in Ireland date from periods when their home tax system was a "worldwide tax" system (e.g. UK pre–2009, and U.S. pre–2018); and is why there are no non–U.S./non–UK multinationals in Ireland's top 50 firms. [[File:Ireland Trade Good Discrepancy (1995-2017).png|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' The Q1 2015 restructuring of Apple's non-U.S. IP to Ireland ([[leprechaun economics]]), is the largest [[BEPS]] action in history.
[[Brad Setser]] & Cole Frank ([[Council on Foreign Relations|CoFR]]).]] As with all [[tax havens]], Ireland's GDP is artificially inflated by BEPS accounting flows. This distortion escalated in Q1 2015 when Apple executed the largest BEPS transaction in history, on-shoring $300 billion of non–U.S. IP to Ireland (called "[[leprechaun economics]]"). It forced the [[Central Bank of Ireland]] to abandon GDP in 2017, and replace with [[modified gross national income]] (GNI*), which removes part, but not all, of the distortions by BEPS tools. Irish GDP was 162% of Irish GNI* in 2017.{{efn|name="gnigdp"|In contrast, EU–28 2017 GDP was 100% of EU–28 2017 GNI).}} [[File:Uncovering Offshore Financial Centers Figure 3 Network of ownership flows between countries.jpg|thumb|'''[[Corporate tax haven]]''': Ireland is ranked as one of the largest global [[Conduit and Sink OFCs|Conduit OFCs]] in terms of connections to tax havens, the largest global [[Tax haven#Tax haven lists|Tax Haven]] in terms of quantum of profits shielded, and the 3rd-largest global [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]].]] Ireland's corporation tax regime is integrated with Ireland's [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] tax schemes (e.g. [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPVs]] and [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)|QIAIFs]]), which offer traditional [[tax haven]]-type tools to give confidential routes out of the Irish corporate tax system to Ireland's favoured [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFC]], Luxembourg, which is 50% of all outbound Irish FDI. This functionality has made Ireland one of the largest global [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFCs]], and the third largest global [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]]. Irish privacy and data protection laws hide Irish tax tools from public scrutiny. There is evidence Ireland behaves like a "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Captured state|captured state]]", fostering tax avoidance schemes. Ireland is labelled a {{slink|#Corporate tax haven}}. As {{slink|#Countermeasures to Ireland}}, the U.S. [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] (TCJA) moves the U.S to a "territorial tax" system. The TJCA's GILTI–FDII–BEAT tax regime has seen U.S. IP–heavy multinationals (e.g. Pfizer), forecast 2019 effective tax rates that are similar to those of prior U.S. [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]] to Ireland (e.g. Medtronic). Ireland's corporate tax regime is also threatened by the EU's desire to introduce EU–wide anti-BEPS tool regimes (e.g. the 2020 Digital Services Tax, and the [[Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base|CCCTB]]). ==Tax system== ===Tax rates=== [[File:Irish Corporation Tax Rates (1974 to 2016).png|thumb|Irish corporate tax rates (1974 to 2016). Source: [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]].]] {{See also|#Historical rates (1994–2018)}} {{As of | November 2018}}, there are two rates of corporation tax ("CT") in the Republic of Ireland:{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/invest-in-ireland/ireland-corporate-tax|title=Corporate Tax regime in Ireland|publisher=[[IDA Ireland|Industrial Development Authority]]|date=2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/IDAIreland/media/docs/publications/Taxation_2016.pdf|title=Corporate Taxation in Ireland 2016|publisher=[[IDA Ireland|Industrial Development Authority]]|date=2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/companies-and-charities/corporation-tax-for-companies/corporation-tax/index.aspx|title=Irish Corporation Tax Portal|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=2018}} *a 12.5% ''headline rate''{{efn|name="ETR"|In ''[[#ETR|Effective Tax Rates]]'' it is shown that Ireland's true CT tax rate for foreign multinationals is between 0% to 3% depending on what particular Irish BEPS tools are used. ''[[#ETR|Effective Tax Rates]]'' also shows that the ''aggregate'' CT tax rate in Ireland is between 2% and 4.5% depending on various assumptions.}} for '''trading income''' (or active businesses income in the Irish tax code); ''trading'' relates to conducting a business, not ''investment trading''; *a 25.0% ''headline rate''{{efn|Ireland offers specific Central Bank of Ireland–regulated SPVs that foreign investors in passive Irish income can use avoid the 25% rate (and all other Irish taxes and duties), on Irish assets. The main vehicles are the Irish [[QIAIF]] and the Irish [[Section 110 SPV]]. Public tax scandals in Ireland in 2016, revealed because Irish Section 110 SPVs have to file Irish public accounts, led to the Central Bank of Ireland to introduce the [[L–QIAIF]] vehicle to replace the Section 110 SPV for foreign investors who want to avoid the 25% passive income tax in a confidential manner. QIAIFs and L–QIAIFs do not have to file Irish public accounts; instead filing confidential accounts with the Central Bank of Ireland which are protected under the ''Central Bank Secrecy Act'' of 1942.{{cite web|url= https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/central-bank-secrecy-law-will-limit-public-disclosure-of-key-documents-1.2079188|title=Powerful Central Bank secrecy laws limit public disclosure of key documents|date=January 2016|publisher=Irish Times}}}} for '''non-trading income''' (or also called '''passive income''' in the Irish tax code); covering investment income (e.g. income from buying and selling assets), rental income from real estate, net profits from foreign trades, and income from certain land dealings and income from oil, gas and mineral exploitations in Ireland. ===Key aspects=== [[File:OECD 2018 Corporate Tax Rates.png|thumb|2018 ''headline'' corporate tax rates for all 35 OECD members (pre and post the 2017 U.S [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|TCJA]]).{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/us-corporate-income-tax-more-competitive/|title=The United States’ Corporate Income Tax Rate is Now More in Line with Those Levied by Other Major Nations|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=12 February 2018|author=Kyle Pomerleau}}]] {{As of | November 2018}}, the key attributes that tax experts note regarding the Irish corporate tax system are as follows: * Low headline rate. At 12.5%, Ireland has one of the lowest ''headline''{{efn|name="ETR"}} [[tax rates in Europe]] (Hungary 9% and Bulgaria 10% are lower); OECD average is 24.9%.{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/corporate-income-tax-rates-around-the-world-2017/|title=Lowest and Highest Global Global Corporate Tax Rates|author=Kari Jahnsen|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=September 2017}} * Transparent. Many of Ireland's corporation tax tools are OECD–whitelisted,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-awarded-high-oecd-rating-on-tax-transparency-1.3194255|title=Ireland awarded high OECD rating on tax transparency|publisher=Irish Times|date=22 August 2017}} and Ireland has one of the lowest '''secrecy scores''' in the 2018 [[Financial Secrecy Index|FSI rankings]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/we-have-no-problem-with-irish-tax-system-oecd-36566931.html|title='We have no problem with Irish tax system' - OECD|publisher=Irish Times|date=5 February 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/ireland-does-not-engage-in-harmful-tax-competition-says-european-commission-1.2895658?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fireland-does-not-engage-in-harmful-tax-competition-says-european-commission-1.2895658| title=Ireland does not engage in “harmful tax competition” says European Commission| publisher=Irish Times|date=6 December 2016}} * "Worldwide tax". Ireland is one of 6 remaining countries that use a "worldwide tax" system (Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico).{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/worldwide-taxation-very-rare/|title=Worldwide Taxation is Very Rare|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=February 2015}} * No "thin capitalisation". Ireland has no [[thin capitalisation]] rules, which means that Irish corporates can be financed with 100% debt, and 0% equity.{{cite web|url=http://www.dilloneustace.com/download/1/Publications/Tax/Holding%20Companies%20in%20Ireland.pdf|title=Holding Companies in Ireland|publisher=Dillon Eustace Law Partners (Dublin)|date=2016}} * [[Double Irish]] residency. Before 2015, Irish CT was based where a company was "managed and controlled" versus registered; the "[[Double Irish]]" ends in 2020. * [[Double Irish arrangement#Single malt|Single Malt]] residency. Post closure of the Double Irish to new entrants in 2015, it can be recreated by wordings in selective tax treaties (e.g. Malta and UAE). * Extensive treaties. {{As of| March 2018}}, Ireland has bilateral tax treaties with 73 countries (the 74th, Ghana, is pending).{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tax-agreements/double-taxation-treaties/index.aspx?page=u|title=Double Irish Taxation Treaties|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=March 2018}} * Holding company regime. Built for [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]], it gives Irish–based holding companies tax relief on withholding taxes, foreign dividends and CGT.{{cite web|url=http://www.btconsulting.ie/page17/files/UK%20PLC%20Inversion.pdf|title=Inversion of UK plcs to Ireland|publisher=BT Consulting|date=2009|quote= However, in recent times, it is Ireland’s treatment of profits made by foreign subsidiaries of Irish resident companies that has been attracting attention and encouraging, in particular, UK firms to move their holding companies to Ireland and become tax resident there in order to reduce their tax burden.}} * [[Intellectual property]] regime. Built for the BEPS tools of U.S. technology and life sciences firms, recognises a wide range of [[Intellectual capital|intellectual assets]] that can be charged against Irish tax; the [[CAIA arrangement]]. * Knowledge Development Box. Ireland created the first OECD–compliant KDB in 2016 to support its IP–based BEPS tools. ===Yearly returns (2001–2017)=== [[File:Irish Corporation Tax as % of Total Tax (1989 to 2012).jpg|thumb|Irish Corporation Tax as a % Irish Exchequer Tax has between between 10% to 16% of Total Irish Tax. Source: [[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]{{cite web|url=https://taxpolicy.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/CT-Strategy-Presentation-for-Website-FINAL.pdf | title=Ireland’s Corporation Tax Strategy | author=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]] | date=1 April 2013}}]] [[File:Irish Corporation Tax (% of GDP and % of Total Tax).png|thumb|Irish Corporation Tax as % of Irish GDP, and as % of Total Irish Gross{{efn|name="gross"}} Tax (1974 to 2016). Source: OECD.]] The trends in Irish corporation tax ("CT") receipts to the Irish Exchequer were:{{cite web|url=http://www.fiscalcouncil.ie/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/AN-10-Challenges-Forecasting-Irish-Corporation-Tax-Final-Web.pdf|title=Irish Corporate Tax Forecasting Analytical Note 10| publisher=[[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=September 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/corporate/documents/research/ct-analysis-2018.pdf|title=Corporation Tax: 2017 Payments and 2016 Returns|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.audit.gov.ie/en/Find-Report/Publications/Report%20on%20the%20Accounts%20of%20the%20Public%20Services/Report%20on%20the%20Accounts%20of%20the%20Public%20Services%202016.html|title=Report on the Accounts of the Public Services 2016 (Chapter 20: Corporation Tax Receipts)|publisher=[[Comptroller and Auditor General of Ireland]] |date=April 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.finance.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/180103-End-December-2017-Exchequer-Returns-Presentation.pdf|title=End December 2017 Exchequer Returns Presentation|publisher=Department of Finance|date=3 January 2018}} * Foreign firms pay 80% of Irish ''CT Revenue'' (notwithstanding that large U.S.–controlled [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversions]] to Ireland, are classed as ''Irish'' firms).{{cite web|url=https://fora.ie/multinational-tax-ireland-2767900-May2016/|title=Most of Ireland's huge corporate tax haul last year came from foreign firms|publisher=[[Sunday Business Post]] FORA|date=14 May 2016}} * Irish ''CT Revenues'' jump in 2015, the year of Apple's [[leprechaun economics]] re-structure of its BEPS tools. * Since Apple's 2015 re-structure, Irish ''CT Revenue'' as a % of ''Total Irish Exchequer Tax Revenue'' is at its pre-crisis peak of over 16% (OECD average is 7.5%); * Irish ''CT Revenue'' has been 10 to 16% of ''Total Irish Exchequer Tax Revenue'' (see graphic). * The concentration of the ''Top 10 Irish CT Payers'' has risen post the crisis, despite the fact that Irish banks stopped paying Irish CT due to accumulated losses.{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/corporate/documents/research/corporation-tax.pdf|title=Corporation Tax – A Note on the Context and Concentration of Payments|publisher=[[Revenue Commissioners]]|date=October 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0621/884543-corporation/|title=20 multinationals paid half of all Corporation tax paid in 2016|publisher=RTE News|date=21 June 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: left;" |Table 3: Irish Corporation Tax (CT) Revenues: 2001–2007 (€ billion) |- !style="width:120px;text-align:left"|Calendar

{{Main article|Taxation in the Republic of Ireland}} [[File:Distribution of Irish Exchequer Tax (2000 to 2017).png|thumb|upright=1.5|Distribution of Irish Exchequer Tax Revenues.{{cite web|url=https://www.finance.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/annual-taxation-report.pdf|title=ANNUAL TAXATION REPORT |publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]|quote=Figure A.1: share of tax revenue 2000-2017, per cent|date=January 2018|page=12}}]] Each year, the [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]] is required to produce a report on ''Estimates for Receipts and Expenditure'' for the coming year. The table below, is extracted from the "Tax Revenues" section of the report for the prior-year (e.g. the 2017 column is from the 2018 report), by which time the "Tax Revenues" for that year are largely known (although still subject to further revision in later years). [[File:Irish Exchequer Tax Revenues to GDP and GNI.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Irish Exchequer Tax Revenues as % of GDP / GNI*.]] The "Tax Revenues" quoted are ''Exchequer Tax Revenues'', and do not include ''Appropriations-in-Aid'' ("A–in–A") items, the largest being Social Security (or PRSI) which for 2015 was €10.2 billion, and other smaller items. Irish Personal Income tax, and the two main Irish consumption taxes of VAT and Excise, have consistently been circa 80% of the total Irish Exchequer Tax Revenue, with the balance being Corporate tax. [[File:Impact of Ireland Corporation Tax Regime on Ireland's Economy.jpg|thumb|Effect of Ireland's Corporate Tax system on Ireland's relative GNI-per-capita to the EU average{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2015/11/11/how-ireland-became-an-offshore-financial-centre/|title=How Ireland became a tax haven and offshore financial centre|publisher=[[Nicholas Shaxson]], [[Tax Justice Network]]|date=11 November 2015|quote=The simple popular story is that Ireland used its 12.5 percent low corporate tax rate, and tax loopholes, to attract foreign multinational corporations, and built the so-called “Celtic Tiger” Irish economic boom on the back of that, helping Ireland become the single largest location outside the US for the declared pre-tax profits of U.S. firms.}}]] Ireland's economic model was transformed from a predominantly agricultural-based economy to a knowledge-based economy, when the EU agreed to waive EU State-aid rules to allow Ireland's '''special rate''' of 10% for manufacturing (created in 1980–81 with the EU's agreement), to be extended to the [[special economic zone]] called the [[International Financial Services Centre]] ("IFSC") in Dublin city centre in 1987. The transformation was accelerated when Ireland's standard corporate tax rate was reduced from 40% to 12.5% (phased in from 1996–2003), in response to the EU's 1996–1998 decision to withdraw the State-aid waiver. The passing of the ''1997 Taxes and Consolidated Acts'' laid the legal foundations for the [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tools used by U.S. multinationals in Ireland (e.g. the [[Double Irish]], the [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]] and the [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPV]]), to achieve an effective Irish CT rate, or ''[[#ETR|ETR]]'', of 0–3%.{{efn|name="ETR"}} While low CT rates (and evern lower [[#ETR|effective tax rates]]), are a central part of Irish tax policy, non–CT ''[[Taxation in the Republic of Ireland]]'' is closer to EU–28 and OECD averages.{{efn|However, only when Irish [[Modified gross national income]] (or GNI*) is used for comparision, rather than Irish GDP which is artificially inflated and distorted by BEPS flows. See [[#Distortion of GDP]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.finance.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/131017-BOC-DEW-Slides.pdf|title=The structure of Ireland’s tax system and options for growth enhancing reform|author=Brendan O'Connor|publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]}}{{cite journal|url=https://www.esr.ie/article/view/93|title=The Structure of Ireland’s Tax System and Options for Growth Enhancing Reform|author=Brendan O'Connor|publisher=The Economic and Social Review Quarterly|volume=44|issue=4|date=August 2013}} Ireland's policy is summarised by the OECD's ''Hierarchy of Taxes'' pyramid (reproduced in the [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]] Tax Strategy Group's 2011 corporate tax policy document).{{Cite web|title=Tax Strategy Group: Irish Corporate Taxation|page=3|url=http://taxpolicy.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/11.19-Corporation-Tax.pdf|date=October 2011|publisher=[[Department of Finance (Ireland)]]}} As shown in {{slink|#Yearly returns (2001–2017)}}, annual Irish CT has been between 10 and 16 percent of annual Total Irish Tax from circa 1994 to 2018. From 2000–2014, Ireland's Total Tax-to-GDP ratio was circa 27–30%, versus the OECD average of 33%.{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/tax/revenue-statistics-ireland.pdf|title=Revenue Statistics 2017 - Ireland|publisher=[[OECD]]|date=2017}} However, since Apple's [[leprechaun economics]] Irish restructuring artificially inflated Ireland's GDP by 34.3% in 2015, Ireland's Tax-to-GDP ratio had fallen to the bottom of the OECD range at under 23%. [[File:OECD Hierarchy of Taxes.png|thumb|Recreation of the OECD "Hierarchy of Taxes" used by Ireland.]] In June 2018, international tax academics confirmed that Ireland was the largest global [[tax haven]], exceeding the combined flows of the entire Caribbean tax haven system. As international tax academics have shown, being a leading corporate tax haven has been a prosperous economy strategy for Ireland.{{cite journal|url=https://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/39181/921.pdf?sequence=1|title=Do Tax Havens Flourish|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|journal=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], ''Tax Policy and the Economy''|quote=ABSTRACT: Per capita real GDP in tax haven countries grew at an average annual rate of 3.3 percent between 1982 and 1999, which compares favorably to the world average of 1.4 percent.|volume=19|page=65-99|date=2005}} However, as the tax academics also predicted, the artificial distortion of Ireland's economic data, and GDP in particular, by BEPS flows, led to a large credit bubble during 2003–2007 (due to the mispricing of Ireland's credit), and an eventual credit–property–banking crisis in 2008–2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.socialeurope.eu/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/p_imk_wp_175_2017.pdf|author=Heike Joebges|title=CRISIS RECOVERY IN A COUNTRY WITH A HIGH PRESENCE OF FOREIGN-OWNED COMPANIES: The Case of Ireland |publisher=IMK Macroeconomic Policy Institute, [[Hans-Böckler-Stiftung]]|date=January 2017}} Ireland's main foreign multinationals are from periods when their home jurisdiction had a "worldwide tax" system (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''), and since the UK switched to a "territorial tax" system in 2009–12, Ireland has been almost exclusively a U.S. corporate–[[tax haven]] (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). In October 2014, the ''[[The Guardian]]'' quoted the Irish lead singer of ''[[U2]]'', ''[[Bono]]'' as saying that "his country’s tax policies have "brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known"".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/12/bono-tax-laws-bring-ireland-prosperity-apple-google-u2|title=Bono: controversial tax laws have brought Ireland the only prosperity it’s ever known|date=12 October 2014|author=Rupert Neate|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|quote=In an interview with the Observer, the Irish singer says his country’s tax policies have “brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known”. Bono said: “We are a tiny little country, we don’t have scale, and our version of scale is to be innovative and to be clever, and tax competitiveness has brought our country the only prosperity we’ve known. “That’s how we got these companies here … We don’t have natural resources, we have to be able to attract people.”}} In April 2016, award-winning Irish writer, [[Fintan O'Toole]] labeled Ireland's focus on being a U.S. corporate tax haven as the core economic model, as Ireland's OBI, (or "One Big Idea").{{cite web| url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/fintan-o-toole-us-taxpayers-growing-tired-of-ireland-s-one-big-idea-1.2615065|title=US taxpayers growing tired of Ireland’s one big idea|author=[[Fintan O'Toole]]|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=16 April 2016|quote=The losses to the US budget from corporate tax avoidance are now out of control. The US loses as much as $111 billion each year due to corporate tax dodging – and let’s be honest, Ireland is implicated in a significant amount of this. [...] This is arguably the biggest economic challenge facing Ireland over the next decade}} ===Multinational economy=== [[File:EUROSTAT Ireland Gross Operating Surplus by Controlling Country, €million 2015.png|thumb|upright=1.0|Dominance of U.S. firms. Irish corporate ''Gross Operating Surplus'' (i.e. profits), by the controlling country of the company (note: a material part of the Irish figure is also from U.S. [[#Corporate tax inversions|tax inversion]]s who are U.S.–controlled). Eurostat (2015).{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.com/2018/06/who-shifts-profits-to-ireland.html|title=Who shifts profits to Ireland|publisher=Economic Incentives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=18 June 2018|quote=Eurostat’s structural business statistics give a range of measures of the business economy broken down by the controlling country of the enterprises. Here is the Gross Operating Surplus generated in Ireland in 2015 for the countries with figures reported by Eurostat.}}]] U.S.–controlled multinationals, either legally based in the U.S. or legally based in Ireland (e.g. tax inversions), dominate Ireland's economy. In June 2018, the ''American Chamber of Commerce (Ireland)'' estimated the value of U.S. investment in Ireland was €334 billion, which compared to 2017 Irish [[GNI*]] [[Modified gross national income#Irish GDP versus Modified GNI (2009–2017)|of €181.2 billion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/denouncing-ireland-as-a-tax-haven-is-as-dated-as-calling-it-homophobic-because-of-our-past-37032219.html|title=Denouncing Ireland as a tax haven is as dated as calling it homophobic because of our past|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 June 2018|quote=The total value of US business investment in Ireland - ranging from data centres to the world's most advanced manufacturing facilities - stands at $387bn (€334bn) - this is more than the combined US investment in South America, Africa and the Middle East, and more than the BRIC countries combined.}} In January 2018, [[Eurostat]] used 2015 data to show the ''gross operating surplus'' of foreign companies in Ireland was almost exclusively from U.S. companies, with the UK was a distant second, and little other foreign firm activity (see graphic). Not only did U.S. companies rank ahead of Irish companies, but a material quantum of the ''gross operating surplus'' attributed to Irish companies, is from U.S. tax inversion such as [[Medtronic]], [[Eaton Corporation|Eaton]] and [[Allergan]], who are in effect, U.S.–controlled multinationals, and have little attachment to Ireland. In 2016–2017, foreign multinationals, being entirely U.S.–controlled: * Directly employed one–quarter of the Irish private sector workforce;{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/investment/IRELAND-trade-investment-statistical-country-note.pdf|title=IRELAND Trade and Statistical Note 2017|publisher=OECD|date=2017|pages=2-5}} * Paid an average wage of €85k (€17.9bn wage roll on 210,443 staff) versus the Irish Industrial wage of €35k;{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/docs/publications/ida_strategy_final|title=Winning FDI 2015–2019 Strategy|publisher=IDA Ireland|date=March 2015}} * Directly contributed €28.3 billion annually in taxes, wages and capital spending; * Paid 80% of all Irish corporation and Irish business taxes; * Paid 50% of all Irish salary taxes (due to higher paying jobs), 50% of all Irish VAT, and 92% of all Irish customs and excise duties;{{efn|These figures were stated by Suzanne Kelly, a leading Irish tax expert and tax barrister, and the Past President of the Irish Tax Institute; but they are not fully verifiable from public sources.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/multinationals-tax-contribution-ireland-facts-2972139-Sep2016/|title=FactCheck: How much do multinationals actually contribute in taxes?|publisher=thejournal.ie|date=9 September 2016}}}} * Created 57% of private sector non–farm value–add: 40% of value–add in Irish services and 80% of value–add in Irish manufacturing); * Made up 25 of the top 50 Irish companies (by 2017 turnover) (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). ===Multinational features=== The main features regarding foreign multinationals in Ireland are: * '''They are almost exclusively U.S.''' U.S.–controlled multinationals are 25 of the top 50 firms in Ireland, and 70% of top 50 firm revenue (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). This includes U.S. multinationals that are legally headquartered in Ireland (e.g. [[Medtronic]]), but who are run from the U.S. (e.g. all senior executives and the main offices are in the U.S.).{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/article.php?id=2116085|title=Most of Ireland’s biggest companies aren’t Irish at all | publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|date=22 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.top1000.ie/companies|title=2017: Ireland's Top 1,000 Companies | publisher=[[Irish Times]]| date=2018}} * '''The are from countries with "worldwide tax" systems'''. Tax academics show that firms from "territorial tax" systems (over 95% of all countries),{{efn|name="territorial"|"Territorial tax" systems have the flexibility to apply much lower tax rates on foreign sourced income to incentivise companies to maintain their headquarters at home (e.g. Germany applies a 5% tax on foreign profits).{{Cite web|title = A Territorial Tax System Would Create Jobs and Raise Wages for U.S. Workers|url = https://www.heritage.org/taxes/report/territorial-tax-system-would-create-jobs-and-raise-wages-us-workers|publisher = The Heritage Foundation|date = 12 September 2013}} Prior to the 2017 U.S. ''[[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]]'', the U.S. was one of 7 remaining jurisdictions (e.g. Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico and the U.S.), to operate a "worldwide tax" system which applied a fixed single high rate of 35% tax on all worldwide income.{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2013/wp13205.pdf|title=Territorial vs. Worldwide Corporate Taxation: Implications for Developing Countries|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=2013|page=4}}}} make little use of [[tax havens]].{{cite journal| url = https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2831&context=articles|title=Multinational Firms and Tax Havens|author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Anna Gumpert|author3=Monika Schnitzer|date=2016|journal=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]]|page=714|quote=Germany taxes only 5% of the active foreign business profits of its resident corporations. [..] Furthermore, German firms do not have incentives to structure their foreign operations in ways that avoid repatriating income. Therefore, the tax incentives for German firms to establish tax haven affiliates are likely to differ from those of U.S. firms and bear strong similarities to those of other G–7 and OECD firms.|volume=98|issue=4}} The only non–U.S. foreign firms in the top 50 Irish firms are UK firms from pre–2009, after which the UK switched to a "territorial tax" system.{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/tax-reform-uk-reversed-tide-corporate-tax-inversions/|title=How Tax Reform solved UK inversions|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|author=William McBride|date=14 October 2014}}{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/united-kingdom-s-experience-inversions/|title=The United Kingdom's Experience with Inversions|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]||author=Kyle Pomerleau|date=5 April 2016}} In December 2017, the U.S. switched to a hybrid-"territorial tax" system.{{efn|name="hybrid"}} * '''They are concentrated.''' The top–20 corporate taxpayers pay 50% of all Irish corporate taxes, while the top–10 pay 40% of all Irish corporate taxes. Post–[[leprechaun economics]], Apple, Ireland's largest company by turnover (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''), constitutes over one–quarter of Ireland's GDP.{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2018/0417/955163-iphone-effect-on-irish-economy/|title=Quarter of Irish economic growth due to Apple's iPhone, says IMF|publisher=RTE News|date=17 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/iphone-exports-accounted-for-quarter-of-irish-economic-growth-in-2017-imf-1.3464658|title=iPhone exports accounted for quarter of Irish economic growth in 2017 - IMF|publisher=Irish Times|date=17 April 2018}} The top 10 U.S.–controlled multinationals comfortably account for over 50% of Irish 2017 GDP.{{efn|Apple's Q1 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] re-structure increased Irish GDP by up to 34.4% (e.g. Apple is at least one-quarter of Irish GDP). The next 9 largest U.S.–controlled multinationals have a combined 2017 Irish turnover of €144.0 billion that exceeds Apple's 2017 Irish turnover of €119.2 billion (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]'')}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c69ed976-fbab-11e7-9b32-d7d59aace167|title=Ireland enjoys tax boom but fears a reckoning|publisher=Financial Times|date=31 January 2018}} * '''They are mostly technology and life sciences.''' To use Ireland's main BEPS tools, a multinational needs to have [[intellectual property]] (or "IP"), which is then converted into [[intellectual capital]] and [[royalty payment]] plans, which ''shift profits'' from high–tax locations to Ireland. Most global IP is concentrated in the technology and life sciences industries (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]'').{{cite web|url=https://chicagounbound.uchicago.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2385&context=law_and_economics|title=What Do We Know About Base Erosion and Profit Shifting? A Review of the Empirical Literature|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|year=2014|quote= It focuses particularly on the dominant approach within the economics literature on income shifting, which dates back to Hines and Rice (1994) and which we refer to as the “Hines–Rice” approach.|page=1}}{{cite book | url= http://www.wipo.int/edocs/pubdocs/en/wipo_pub_943_2017.pdf | title=WIPO IP Facts and Figures 2017 | date=April 2018 | isbn=9789280529142 | publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]]}} * '''They use Ireland to shield all non–U.S. profits, not just EU profits, from the US "worldwide tax" system.''' In 2016, Facebook recorded global revenues of $27 billion, while Facebook (Ireland) paid €30 million in Irish tax on Irish revenues of €13 billion (half of all global revenues).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/technology/facebook-paid-just-30m-tax-in-ireland-despite-earning-12bn-36362527.html|title=Facebook paid just €30m tax in Ireland despite earning €12bn|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Adrian Weckler|date=29 November 2017}}{{efn|Similarly, when the EU introduced the [[GDPR]] regulations in 2018, Facebook disclosed that all of its non–U.S. accounts (circa 1.9 billion, of which 1.5 billion were non-E.U), were legally based in Dublin.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-privacy-eu-exclusive/exclusive-facebook-to-put-1-5-billion-users-out-of-reach-of-new-eu-privacy-law-idUSKBN1HQ00P|title=Exclusive: Facebook to put 1.5 billion users out of reach of new EU privacy law|publisher=[[Reuters]]|author=David Ingram|date=18 April 2018}}}} Similarly, Google also runs most of its non–U.S. revenue and profits through its Dublin operation.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/nov/04/google-pays-47m-euros-tax-ireland-22bn-euros-revenue|title=Google pays €47m in tax in Ireland on €22bn sales revenue|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|author=Simon Bowers|date=4 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1026612.shtml|title=Google booked 41% of global revenues in Ireland in 2012; A leprechaun's gold?|publisher=Finfacts.ie|date=30 September 2013}} * '''They artificially inflate Irish GDP by 62%.''' All [[tax havens]] have a [[Tax haven#Inflated GDP-per-capita|distorted GDP]] due to the effect of BEPS flows. Apple's Q1 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] re-structuring of their Double Irish BEPS tool into a CAIA BEPS tool, increased the distortion to such a level that in February 2017, the [[Central Bank of Ireland|Central Bank]] replaced Irish GDP with [[Modified gross national income|GNI*]]. In 2017, Irish GDP was [[Modified gross national income#Irish GDP versus Modified GNI (2009–2017)|162%]] of 2017 GNI*.{{efn|name="gnigdp"}} * '''They pay effective tax rates of 0–3%.''' Irish [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]] quote an effective 2015 CT rate of 9.8%, but this omits profits deemed not taxable.{{cite web|url=https://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/Archive2013/Country%20Reports/Ireland.pdf|title=TAX JUSTICE NETWORK: Ireland Financial Secrecy Index Country Report 2014|quote=Misleadingly, studies cited by the Irish Times and other outlets suggest that the effective tax rate is close to the headline 12.5 percent rate – but this is a fictional result based on a theoretical ‘standard firm with 60 employees’ and no exports: it is entirely inapplicable to transnationals. Though there are various ways to calculate effective tax rates, other studies find rates of just 2.5-4.5 percent.|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=November 2014}} The US [[Bureau of Economic Analysis]] gives an effective 2015 Irish CT rate of 2.5%. BEA agrees with the Irish CT rates of Apple, Google and Facebook (<1%),{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/technology/facebook-paid-just-30m-tax-in-ireland-despite-earning-12bn-36362527.html|title=Facebook paid just €30m tax in Ireland despite earning €12bn|publisher=Irish Indepdenent|date=29 November 2017}} and the CT rates of Irish BEPS tools (0-3%).{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/almost-half-of-irish-registered-firms-profits-cannot-be-taxed-1.1836061|title=Almost half of Irish-registered firms’ profits ‘cannot be taxed’|publisher=Irish Times|date=18 June 2014}} ({{slink|#Effective tax rate (ETR)}}) ===Multinational job focus=== {{see also|Corporate haven#Employment tax}} Ireland's corporate BEPS tools emphasise job creation (either of Irish employees or of foreign employees to Ireland). To use Irish BEPS tools, and their [[#ETR|ETR]]s of 0–3%,{{efn|name="ETR"}} the multinational must meet conditions on the [[intellectual property]] ("IP") they will be using as part of their Irish BEPS tool. This is outlined in the Irish Finance Acts particular to each scheme, but in summary, the multinational must:{{Cite web|title=Intangible Assets Scheme under Section 291A Taxes Consolidation Act 1997 |url = https://www.revenue.ie/ga/tax-professionals/historic-material/tax-briefing/2010/tax-briefing-issue-09-2010.pdf|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=2010}}{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-09/09-02-05.pdf|title=Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets under section 291A of the Taxes Consolidation Act 1997 (Part 9 / Chapter2)|publisher=[[Irish Revenue Commissioners]]|date=February 2018}} * Prove they are carrying out a "relevant trade" on the IP in Ireland (i.e. Ireland is not just an "empty shell" through which IP passes en route to another tax haven); * Prove the level of Irish employment doing the "relevant activities" on the IP is consistent with the Irish tax relief being claimed (the ratio has never been disclosed);{{efn|There are fewer cases of U.S. technology multinationals conducting genuine software programming origination in Ireland. The "high-value" Irish jobs tend to be "[[language localisation]]" work (e.g. converting software into different languages) or "sales and marketing". These are sufficient to meet the Irish [[Revenue Commissioners]] criteria for a "relevant trade" and "relevant activities".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/work/ireland-s-top-tech-companies-who-pays-the-most-1.2526778|title=Google UK employees paid double their Irish equivalent|publisher=Irish Times|date=February 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/may/29/apple-tax-profits-ireland-cork|title=Apple's multi-billion dollar, low-tax profit hub: Knocknaheeny, Ireland|publisher=The Guardian|date=29 May 2013}}}} * Show that the average wages of the Irish employees are consistent with such a "relevant trade" (i.e. must be "high-value" jobs earning +€60,000–€90,000 per annum);{{efn|In March 2018, [[IDA Ireland]] disclosed that foreign multinationals paid €17.9 billion in wage on 210,443 Irish staff, or €85k per employee ("high-value" jobs) in 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.idaireland.com/newsroom/publications/ireland-s-economic-and-competitiveness-update-q1|title=IDA Ireland Competitiveness|publisher=IDA Ireland|date=March 2018}}}} * Put this into an approved "business plan" (agreed with Revenue Commissioners and other State bodies, such as IDA Ireland), for the term of the tax relief scheme; * Agree to suffer "clawbacks" of the Irish tax relief granted (i.e. pay the full 12.5% level), if they leave before the end plan (5 years for schemes started after February 2013) The percentage of Irish wage-to-profits has never been disclosed, however, commentators imply the Irish wage-roll needs to be circa 2–3% of gross Irish profits: * Apple employed 6,000 people in 2014, and at say €100,000 cost per employee gives a €600 million wage-roll on 2014 Irish profits of €25 billion (see table below),{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/revealed-eight-facts-you-may-not-know-about-the-apple-irish-plant-36409796.html|title=Revealed Eight facts you may not know about the Apple Irish plant|publisher=Irish Independent|date=15 December 2017}} or 2.4% * Google employed 2,763 people in 2014, and at say €100,000 cost per employee gives a €276 million wage roll on Google 2014 Irish profits of €12 billion,{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/Irish_finance_news/articleDetail.php?Does-Google-Ireland-have-6-000-employees-in-Ireland-649|title=Does Google Ireland have 6,000 employees in Ireland?|publisher=FinFacts|date=2015}} or 2.3% To the extent that the Irish jobs are performing real functions (e.g. the function is not replicated elsewhere in the Group), the cost is not a "employment tax", however, at worst case, the U.S. multinational should incur an aggregate effective Irish corporation tax of 2–6% (actual Irish BEPS tool tax of 0–3%,{{efn|name="ETR"}} plus Irish employment costs of 2–3%). Therefore, as shown in {{slink|#Yearly returns (2001–2017)}}, while Irish CT has consistently been between 10 and 15% of Total Irish Tax, the additional employment contribution made by U.S. multinationals in Ireland, has led to strong growth in overall Irish Total Taxes. ===Top 50 Irish Corporates=== {{anchor|Table 1}} The top 50 Irish companies, ranked by 2017 Irish registered revenues, are as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |+ style="text-align: left;" |Table 1: Top 50 Irish companies by 2017 revenue booked in Ireland (€ billions) |- !style="width:95px;text-align:left"|Rank

2017 revenue (or 26%); | There are no other firms in the top 50 Irish companies from other jurisdictions. }} ==Multinational tax schemes== {{Main article|Double Irish arrangement}} ===Background=== [[File:Ireland Trade Good Discrepancy (1995-2017).png|thumb|'''[[Apple Inc.|Apple (Ireland)]]''' The Q1 2015 restructuring of Apple's non–U.S. IP to Ireland ([[leprechaun economics]]), is the largest [[BEPS]] action in history.
[[Brad Setser]] & Cole Frank ([[Council on Foreign Relations|CoFR]]).]] The tax schemes used by U.S. multinationals in Ireland are called [[base erosion and profit shifting]] (BEPS) tools by tax academics. Whereas Ireland's ''headline'' corporation tax rate is 12.5%, Ireland's BEPS tools enable an [[#ETR|effective tax rate]] of 0% to 3% to be achieved, depending on which BEPS tool is used.{{efn|name="ETR"}} Ireland has been associated with U.S. multinational ''profit shifting'' to avoid taxes since the U.S. IRS produced a list on the 12 January 1981.{{efn|name="gordon1"|Ireland was listed as a ''manufacturing tax haven'' in the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS) (1981) Tax Haven and Their Use by United States Taxpayers (The Gordon Report). Washington, D.C.: Special Council for International Taxation, Internal Revenue Service}}{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/taxhavenstheirus01gord|title=Tax Havens and their use by United States Taxpayers, An Overview|publisher=U.S. Internal Revenue Service|date=12 January 1981}} In February 1994, the U.S. tax academic, [[James R. Hines Jr.]] identified Ireland as one of seven "major" tax havens for U.S. multinational ''profit shifting''.{{cite journal|url=http://taxdoctoralseminar.web.unc.edu/files/2016/02/Hines-Rice.pdf|title=FISCAL PARADISE: FOREIGN TAX HAVENS AND AMERICAN BUSINESS |author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Eric M. Rice|quote=We identify 41 countries and regions as tax havens for the purposes of U. S. businesses. Together the seven tax havens with populations greater than one million (Hong Kong, Ireland, Liberia, Lebanon, Panama, Singapore, and Switzerland) account for 80 percent of total tax haven population and 89 percent of tax haven GDP. |journal=[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] (Harvard/MIT)|date=February 1994|volume=9|issue=1}} During the 2014–2016 [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland|EU investigation into Apple's Irish BEPS tools]], it was revealed that the Irish [[Revenue Commissioners]] had been issuing private rulings on Apple's [[Double Irish]] BEPS tools as far back as 1991; and that Apple, Ireland's largest company, had an ETR of less than 1%. In 2014, the EU Commission forced Ireland to close its Double Irish BEPS tool, however, Ireland had replacements in place: the ''[[Single malt arrangement|Single Malt]]'' (2014), and the ''[[CAIA arrangement|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]'' (CAIA) (2009). When Apple closed its hybrid–Double Irish BEPS tool in Q1 2015 and restructured into the CAIA BEPS tool, the Irish [[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)|Central Statistics Office]] ("CSO") had to re-state Irish 2015 GDP as Apple's CAIA tool had artificially inflated Irish GDP by 34.4%; an event [[Paul Krugman]] christened in July 2016 as [[Leprechaun economics]]. Because the Irish CSO delayed the re-statement and redacted normal economic data to protect Apple's identity,{{cite web|url=http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/newsevents/documents/pr_GDPexplanatorynote.pdf|title=CSO Press Release|publisher=[[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)]]|quote=As a consequence of the overall scale of these additions, elements of the results that would previously been published are now suppressed to protect the confidentiality of the contributing companies, in accordance with the Statistics Act 1993|date=12 July 2016}} it was not until January 2018, that economists could confirm Apple as the source of "leprechaun economics",{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.ie/2018/01/what-apple-did-next.html|title=What Apple did next|publisher=Economic Perspectives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=24 January 2018}} and that at $300 billion, was the largest BEPS action in history. By February 2017, the distortion of Irish economic data by Irish BEPS tools had grown so large, that the [[Central Bank of Ireland]] replaced GDP with [[Modified gross national income|Modified GNI]]; 2017 Irish GNI* is 40% below Irish GDP (see ''[[#Table 2|Table 2]]''}. {{quote box |width=18.5em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote = Of the wider tax environment, O’Rourke thinks the OECD base-erosion and profit-shifting (BEPS) process is "very good" for Ireland. "If BEPS sees itself to a conclusion, it will be good for Ireland." |salign=left|source=[[Feargal O'Rourke]] (2015)
CEO PwC (Ireland)
''Architect'' of the [[Double Irish]]}} In November 2016, Ireland signed the [[Base erosion and profit shifting#OECD BEPS Project|OECD BEPS Multilateral Instrument]] ("MLI") to curb global BEPS tools but opted out of Article 12 to protect the Single Malt and CAIA BEPS tools.{{Cite web|author=Jack Power|title = Ireland resists closing corporation tax ‘loophole’|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/ireland-resists-closing-corporation-tax-loophole-1.3286199|work=The Irish Times|date=10 November 2017|quote=Global legal firm [[Baker McKenzie]], representing a coalition of 24 multinational US software firms, including Microsoft, lobbied [[Michael Noonan (Fine Gael politician)|Michael Noonan]], as [Irish] minister for finance, to resist the [OECD MLI] proposals in January 2017. In a letter to him the group recommended Ireland not adopt article 12, as the changes “will have effects lasting decades” and could “hamper global investment and growth due to uncertainty around taxation”. The letter said that “keeping the current standard will make Ireland a more attractive location for a regional headquarters by reducing the level of uncertainty in the tax relationship with Ireland’s trading partners”}} In March 2018, the [[Financial Stability Forum]] showed Ireland's Debt–based BEPS tools made it the 3rd–largest [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]] in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsb.org/wp-content/uploads/P050318-1.pdf|title=Global Shadow Banking and Monitoring Report: 2017|date=5 March 2018|quote=Jurisdictions with the largest financial systems relative to GDP (Exhibit 2-3) tend to have relatively larger OFI [or Shadown Banking] sectors: Luxembourg (at 92% of total financial assets), the Cayman Islands (85%), Ireland (76%) and the Netherlands (58%)|page=30|publisher=[[Financial Stability Forum]]}} In June 2018, tax academics showed Irish IP–based BEPS tools were artificially distorting ''aggregate'' EU GDP data,{{cite web|url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/ireland-exports-its-leprechaun|quote=Ireland has, more or less, stopped using GDP to measure its own economy. And on current trends [because Irish GDP is distorting EU–28 aggregate data], the eurozone taken as a whole may need to consider something similar.|title=Ireland Exports its Leprechaun|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|date=11 May 2018}} and had artificially inflated the EU–U.S. trade-deficit.{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2018.pdf|title=The Missing Profits of Nations∗|quote=Profit shifting also has a significant effect on trade balances. For instance, after accounting for profit shifting, Japan, the UK, France, and Greece turn out to have trade surpluses in 2015, in contrast to the published data that record trade deficits. According to our estimates, the true trade deficit of the United States was 2.1% of GDP in 2015, instead of 2.8% in the official statistics—that is, a quarter of the recorded trade deficit of the United States is an illusion of multinational corporate tax avoidance.|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Tørsløv|author3=Ludvig Wier|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|page=25|date=8 June 2018}} In June 2018, tax academics confirmed IP–based BEPS tools had made Ireland the world's largest tax haven, and that the $106 billion of annual corporate profits shielded by Irish BEPS tools, exceeded the BEPS flows of the entire Caribbean tax haven system. ===Key features=== ====Intellectual property==== {{see also|Corporate haven#IP–based BEPS tools}} [[File:GIPC Intellectual Property 2018 (Patents Sub-Category).png|thumb|2018 GIPC League Table: ''Patents'' Sub-Category.]] Ireland's main BEPS tools use [[intellectual property]] (IP) to effect the ''profit shift'' from the higher-tax locations to Ireland, via [[royalty payment]] schemes. To avoid incurring Irish corporation tax on these ''shifted profits'', the BEPS tools either send-on the profits to traditional tax havens (with explicit 0% CT rates) via royalty payment schemes (e.g. the Double Irish and Single Malt BEPS tools), or use intangible capital allowances schemes to write-off the profits against Irish tax (e.g. the CAIA BEPS tool).{{cite web|url=http://ftp.zew.de/pub/zew-docs/dp/dp13078.pdf|title=Profit Shifting and "Aggressive" Tax Planning by Multinational Firms|publisher=[[Zentrum für Europäische Wirtschaftsforschung|Centre for European Economic Research]], (ZEW)|author1=Clemens Fuest|author2=Christoph Spengel|author3=Katharina Finke|author4=Jost Heckemeyer|author5=Hannah Nusser|date=15 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://arno.uvt.nl/show.cgi?fid=143915| title=Intellectual Property Tax Planning in the light of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting | publisher=University of Tilburg | date=June 2017}} This is the reason why most U.S. multinationals in Ireland are from the two largest IP–industries, namely technology companies and life sciences; or, are specific companies with valuable industrial patents such as Ingersoll-Rand and Eaton Corporation.{{cite web | url=http://www.fordhamiplj.org/2016/08/30/ip-tax-avoidance-ireland/ | title=Intellectual Property and Tax Avoidance in Ireland | publisher=[[Fordham Intellectual Property, Media & Entertainment Law Journal]] | date=30 August 2016}} Ireland describes its IP–based BEPS tools as being part of its "knowledge economy"; however, U.S. tax academics describe IP as "the leading tax-avoidance vehicle in the world".{{cite web | url=https://www.uclalawreview.org/pdf/62-1-1.pdf | page=4|title=Intellectual Property Law Solutions to Tax Avoidance | publisher=UCLA Law Review | date=2015 | quote=Intellectual property (IP) has become the leading tax avoidance vehicle in the world today.}}{{cite web | url=https://www.bnrbeurs.nl/2017/02/22/the-corporate-tax-avoidance-toolbox/| title=The Corporate Tax Avoidance Toolbox|publisher=B&R Beurs|date=2018}} Despite its small size, Ireland ranks 6th in the 2018 U.S. [[Global Intellectual Property Center]] (GIPC) league table of the top 50 global centres for IP–leglislation, and 4th in the important ''Patents'' sub-category (see graphic opposite).{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobalipcenter.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GIPC_IP_Index_2018.pdf|title=U.S. Chamber International IP Index, 6th Edition, 2018|publisher=[[Global Intellectual Property Center]]|date=February 2018|page=6}} While Ireland's most important BEPS tools are all IP–based, Ireland has other BEPS tools including Transfer Pricing–based BEPS tools (e.g. [[contract manufacturing]]), and Debt–based BEPS tools (e.g. the Irish [[Section 110 SPV]], and the Irish [[L-QIAIF]]). ===="Worldwide Tax" systems==== Ireland's IP–based BEPS tools have only attracted material operations from multinationals whose home jurisdiction had a "worldwide tax" system; namely, the U.K pre–2009, and the U.S. pre–2018 (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''). Ireland has not attracted material technology or life sciences multinationals (outside of a specific plant, under its TP–based ''Contract Manufacturing'' BEPS tool), whose home jurisdiction operates a "territorial tax" system. {{As of|November 2018}}, there are only 6 remaining jurisdictions in the world who operate a "worldwide tax" system, of which Ireland is one (e.g. Chile, Greece, Ireland, Israel, South Korea, Mexico).{{efn|name="territorial"}} In 2016, U.S. tax academic, [[James R. Hines Jr.]] showed firms from "territorial tax" systems make little use of corporate–[[tax havens]], as their tax code applied lower rates to foreign-sourced profits. Hines, with German tax academics, showed the German tax code charged a CT rate of 5% to the foreign profits of German multinationals. Hines was one of the most-cited sources when the U.S. [[Council of Economic Advisors]] advocated switching the U.S. tax code to a "territorial system" in the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]].{{cite web| url= https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/documents/Tax%20Reform%20and%20Wages.pdf|publisher=[[Council of Economic Advisors]]|title=TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT OF 2017 Corporate Tax Reform and Wages: Theory and Evidence|quote=[In the Whitehouse advocating for the TCJA] Applying [[James R. Hines Jr.|Hines and Rice’s (1994)]] findings to a statutory corporate rate reduction of 15 percentage points (from 35 to 20 percent) suggests that reduced profit shifting would result in more than $140 billion of repatriated profit based on 2016 numbers.|date=17 October 2017}} In 2014, the U.S [[Tax Foundation]], reported on how the UK had effectively stopped UK corporates [[#UK inversions|inverting to Ireland]], by switching the UK corporate tax-code to a "territorial system" over 2009-2012. By 2014, the UK ''[[HM Revenue and Customs|HMRC]]'' reported that most of the UK multinationals that had inverted to Ireland had either returned to the UK (e.g., [[WPP plc]], [[United Busines Media plc]], [[Henderson Group plc]]), or were about to be acquired by U.S. multinationals as part of a U.S. corporate tax inversion to Ireland (e.g. [[Shire plc]]).{{efn|name="shire"|Shire's proposed 2014 corporate tax inversion with U.S. pharmaceutical [[AbbVie Inc.]] failed due to the 2016 Obama Administration anti-inversion rules.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/may/08/adderall-shire-takeover-takeda-virgin-money|title=Adderall maker Shire agrees to £46bn takeover by Takeda|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 March 2018|author=Julia Kollewe}} In 2018, Shire agreed to a lower $64 billion bid from Japanese pharmaceutical [[Takeda Pharmaceutical Company|Takeda]], who confirmed they would not be executing a tax inversion to Ireland (Japan's ''headline'' corporate tax rate is 35%), which was attributed to the fact that Japan, like the UK, switched to a "territorial tax" system in 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-shire-m-a-takeda-pharma-deal-exclusiv/shire-willing-to-back-64-billion-takeda-bid-market-signals-doubts-idUSKBN1HV2P4|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=26 April 2018|title=Shire willing to back $64 billion Takeda bid, market signals doubts|author=Ben Martin}}}} ====Distortion of GDP==== {{Main|Modified gross national income|Leprechaun economics}} {{quote box |width=18.5em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote = At this point, multinational profit shifting doesn't just distort Ireland’s balance of payments; it constitutes Ireland’s balance of payments. |salign=left |source=[[Brad Setser]], [[Council on Foreign Relations]], ''Tax Avoidance and the Irish Balance of Payments'' (2018){{cite web|url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/tax-avoidance-and-irish-balance-payments|title=Tax Avoidance and the Irish Balance of Payments|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|author1=[[Brad Setser]]|author2=Cole Frank|date=25 April 2018}}}} An "[[Tax haven#Inflated GDP-per-capita|artificially inflated GDP-per-capita statistic]]", is a known feature of tax havens, due to the BEPS flows.
