O'Rourke]], cousin of the 2008–2011 Irish Finance Minister [[Brian Lenihan Jnr]]) is regarded as its "grand architect".{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-10-28/man-making-ireland-tax-avoidance-hub-globally-proves-local-hero|author=Jesse Drucker|title=Man Making Ireland Tax Avoidance Hub Proves Local Hero | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=28 October 2013|quote=The grand architect of much of that success: Feargal O'Rourke, the scion of a political dynasty who heads the tax practice in PriceWaterhouseCoopers in Ireland}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/scion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fscion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820|author=Fiona Reddan |title=Scion of a prominent political dynasty who gave his vote to accountancy| publisher=Irish Times|date=8 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/controversial-tax-strategies-brainchild-of-orourkes-son-29721835.html| title=Controversial tax strategies brainchild of O'Rourke's son| publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Jesse Drucker|date=3 November 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.broadsheet.ie/2013/10/29/turning-ireland-into-a-global-tax-avoidance-hub/| title=Feargal O'Rourke Turning Ireland Into ‘A Global Tax-Avoidance Hub’| publisher=Broadsheet Ireland|date=29 October 2013}} In 2018, tax academics showed the Double Irish shielded $106 billion of mainly U.S. annual corporate profits from both Irish and U.S. taxation in 2015. As the BEPS tool with which U.S. multinationals built up untaxed offshore reserves of circa US$1 trillion from 2004 to 2017,{{efn|name="bush"|2004 was the date of the last Bush Administration tax amnesty, when pre–2004 offshore untaxed cash was repatriated at a special U.S. tax rate of 5%; in 2018, the TCJA repatriation tax rate was 15.5%.}}{{efn|name="bush2"|While various sources quote the amount of untaxed cash reserves as being closer to USD 2 trillion, a component of this figure represents cash flow that is awaiting reinvestment in the overseas markets, non-cash assets, and U.S. banking flows; the strong consensus is that the pure cash figure is at least over USD 1 trillion.{{cite web|url=https://taxfoundation.org/making-sense-profit-shifting-edward-kleinbard/|title=Making Sense of Profit Shifting: Edward Kleinbard|date=15 March 2015|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|author=Eric Cederwall|quote=We also know that the cash component of that is about $1 trillion. Therefore, we know from this that we're not talking simply about foreign investment in real foreign assets because somewhere in the neighborhood of $1 trillion is in cash and cash equivalents}}}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-real-story-behind-us-companies-off-shore-cash-reserves| title=The real story behind U.S. companies’ offshore cash reserves|publisher=[[McKinsey & Company]]|author1=David Cogman|author2=Tim Koller|quote=By our reckoning, the 500 largest U.S. nonfinancial companies have now accumulated around $1 trillion more than their businesses need. The majority of this is held offshore, in non-U.S. overseas subsidiaries, to avoid the incremental U.S. income taxes they would pay if they repatriated the money under current U.S. laws|date=June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/20/us-corporate-giants-hoarding-over-a-trillion-dollars-apple-microsoft-google| title=U.S. corporate giants hoarding more than a trillion dollars | publisher=[[The Guardian]] |author=Jill Treanor|quote=Earlier this year, anti-poverty charity Oxfam had estimated U.S. companies had $1.4tn in subsidiaries based offshore, while the $1.68tn that Moody’s estimates is being stashed by U.S. companies is a sum equivalent to the size of the Canadian economy|date=20 May 2016}} the Double Irish is the largest tax avoidance tool in history. In 2016, when the [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland|EU levied a €13 billion fine on Apple]], the largest tax fine in history,{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4472500/apple-eu-irish-tax-bill/|title=Apple vs the EU is the biggest tax battle in history | publisher=[[Time Magazine]]|author=RANA FOROOHAR|date=30 August 2016|quote=Ever hear of a Double Irish? It’s not a drink, but one of the dodgy tax strategies that help American companies keep their profits nearly tax free abroad. Such strategies are at the heart of what may well turn out to be the most important corporate tax case in history}} it covered the period 2004–14, during which Apple paid an Irish [[#ETR|ETR]] of <1% on [[EU illegal State aid case against Apple in Ireland#Apple profits|€110.8 billion]] in Irish profits.{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.ie/2018/01/what-apple-did-next.html|title=What Apple did next|publisher=Economic Incentives, [[University College Cork]]|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=24 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-01/pinning-down-apple-s-alleged-0-005-tax-rate-mission-impossible| title=Pinning Down Apple’s Alleged 0.005% Tax Rate Is Nearly Impossible | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=1 September 2016}} Despite the loss of taxes to the U.S. exchequer, it was the EU Commission that forced Ireland to close the Double Irish from January 2015;{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ba95cff0-4fcd-11e4-a0a4-00144feab7de | title=Brussels in crackdown on 'Double Irish' tax loophole| publisher=[[The Financial Times]]| date=October 2014|author1=Alex Barker|author2=Vincent Boland|author3=Vanessa Houlder|quote=Brussels is challenging the “Double Irish” tax avoidance measure prized by big U.S. tech and pharma groups, putting pressure on Dublin to close it down or face a full-blown investigation. [..] The initial enquiries have signalled that Brussels wants Dublin to call time on the tax gambit, which has helped Ireland become a hub for American tech and pharma giants operating in Europe.}} with closure to existing users by 2020.{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/irelands-move-to-close-the-double-irish-tax-loophole-unlikely-to-bother-apple-google-33011 | title=Ireland’s move to close the ‘Double Irish’ tax loophole unlikely to bother Apple, Google| publisher=The Guardian and University of Sydney|author=Anthony Ting|date=October 2014}} ====Single Malt==== {{Main article|Single malt arrangement}} In an October 2013 interview, [[PwC]] tax partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]] ("architect" of the Double Irish, see above), said that: "the days of the Double Irish tax scheme are numbered".{{Cite web|title = Days of 'Double Irish' tax scheme are numbered, says PwC's O'Rourke|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/days-of-double-irish-tax-scheme-are-numbered-says-pwcs-orourke-29709354.html|quote=However, Mr O'Rourke, who is also a cousin of the late Finance Minister Brian Lenihan, told Bloomberg that changes in Ireland and across the globe on tax was inevitable. Mr O'Rourke was also a member of the Government's Commission on Taxation, which sat in 2008 and 2009.|author=Colm Kelpie|publisher=[[The Irish Times]]|date=30 October 2013}} In October 2014, as the EU forced the Irish State to close the Double Irish BEPS tool, the influential U.S. [[National Tax Journal]] published an article by Jeffrey L Rubinger and Summer Lepree, showing that Irish based subsidiaries of U.S. corporations could replace the Double Irish arrangement with a new structure (now known as ''[[#Single Malt|Single Malt]]'').{{Cite web|title = Death of the "Double Irish Dutch Sandwich"? Not so Fast.|url = https://www.taxeswithoutbordersblog.com/2014/10/death-of-the-double-irish-dutch-sandwich-not-so-fast/|publisher=Taxes Without Borders|date=23 October 2014|author1=JEFFREY L. RUBINGER|author2=SUMMER AYERS LEPREE}} The Irish media picked up the article,{{Cite web|title = Multinationals replacing 'Double Irish' with new tax avoidance scheme|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/new-loophole-to-replace-the-double-irish-tax-strategy-30728951.html|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|author=Sarah McCabe|date=9 November 2014|quote=Another sophisticated loophole in the tax system means the removal of the "Double Irish" tax-avoidance strategy won't actually have any real impact for U.S. firms in Ireland seeking to lower their tax bills. An influential U.S. tax journal has found that the Irish subsidiaries of U.S. companies can easily opt to use another loophole, known as the "check the box" rule, to enjoy the same tax benefits created by the Double Irish.}} but when an Irish [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] notified the then Finance Minister, Michael Noonan, he was told to "[[Put on the green jersey]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/dail/2017-11-23/18/|title=Dáil Éireann debate - Thursday, 23 Nov 2017|publisher=House of the Oireachtas|date=23 November 2017|quote=[[Pearse Doherty]]: It was interesting that when [MEP] Matt Carthy put that to the Minister's predecessor (Michael Noonan), his response was that this was very unpatriotic and he should wear the green jersey. That was the former Minister's response to the fact there is a major loophole, whether intentional or unintentional, in our tax code that has allowed large companies to continue to use the Double Irish [called Single Malt].}} A November 2017 report by [[Christian Aid]], titled ''Impossible Structures'', showed how quickly the Single Malt BEPS tool was replacing the Double Irish.{{Cite web|title = ‘Impossible’ structures: tax outcomes overlooked by the 2015 tax Spillover analysis|url = https://www.christianaid.ie/sites/default/files/2018-02/impossible-structures-tax-report.pdf|author=Mike Lewis|publisher=Christian Aid|date=November 2017}}{{Cite web|title = Multinationals replacing 'Double Irish' with new tax avoidance scheme|url = https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/1114/919979-multinationals-using-new-arrangement-to-reduce-tax-bill/|website = RTE News|date = 14 November 2017}}{{Cite web|title = How often is the 'Single Malt' tax loophole used? The government is finding out|url = http://www.thejournal.ie/single-malt-tax-evasion-3698512-Nov2017/|website = [[TheJournal.ie]] |date = 15 November 2017}} The report detailed Microsoft's and Allergen's schemes and extracts from advisers to their clients. In September 2018, the ''[[Irish Times]]'' revealed that U.S. medical device manufacturer [[Teleflex]], had created a Single Malt scheme in July 2018, and reduced their corporate tax rate to circa 3%;{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-s-single-malt-still-aiding-tax-avoidance-1.3640062|title=Ireland's ‘Single Malt’ still aiding tax avoidance|publisher=[[The Irish Times]]|author=Peter Hamilton|date=26 September 2018|quote=Prior to opening a Single Malt structure, Teleflex operated a Double Irish tax structure, according to Christian Aid. “Since Teleflex set up its Double Irish structure, through this and [presumably] other tax strategies its global effective tax rate has dropped to just over 3 percent,” the NGO flagged.}} and that the Irish State were keeping the matter, "under consideration". In November 2018, the Irish Government amended the Ireland–Malta tax treaty to prevent the Single Malt BEPS tool being used between Ireland and Malta (it can still be used with the UAE for example).{{cite web| url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/revenue-to-close-single-malt-tax-loophole-1.3712238 | title=Revenue to close ‘single malt’ tax loophole | publisher=[[Irish Times]] | author=Barry O'Halloran | date=28 November 2018 | quote=Using a structure dubbed the “single malt”, some US multinationals have been using Irish-registered, Malta-resident, companies to cut tax liabilities in countries where they sell their goods and services. Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe confirmed on Tuesday that a new agreement between Revenue and the Maltese tax authorities will close the loophole.}} On the same day the closure was announced, [[LinkedIn]] in Ireland, identified as a user of the Single Malt tool in 2017, announced in filings that it had sold a major IP asset to its parent, Microsoft (Ireland).{{cite web|url= https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/linkedin-s-irish-subsidiary-pays-127m-on-2-67bn-profit-1.3713088 | title=LinkedIn’s Irish subsidiary pays $127m on $2.67bn profit | publisher=[[Irish Times]] | author=Charlie Taylor|date=28 November 2018 | quote=The Irish arm of LinkedIn reported a 20 per cent rise in revenues last year and returned to the black, helped by the disposal of intellectual property assets to its parent Microsoft Ireland.}} In July 2018, it was disclosed in the Irish financial media that Microsoft (Ireland) were preparing a restructure of their Irish BEPS tools into a [[#Microsoft's Green Jersey (2018)|CAIA (or Green Jersey) Irish tax structure]]. ====Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets==== {{Main article|CAIA arrangement}} In June 2009, the Irish State established the ''Commission on Taxation'', to review Ireland's tax regime, and included [[Feargal O'Rourke]] ("architect" of the Double Irish, see above). In September 2009, the Commission recommended that the Irish State provide [[capital allowance]]s for the acquisition of [[intangible assets]], creating the ''[[CAIA arrangement|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]]'' (CAIA) BEPS tool.{{cite web|url=https://researchrepository.ucd.ie/handle/10197/1447| title=Commission on Taxation report 2009|date=September 2009| publisher=UCD Archives}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1017830.shtml| title=Commission on Taxation Report Ireland 2009: Proposed property tax, a carbon tax, and domestic water charges as part of overhaul of Irish tax system|date=7 September 2009| publisher=FinFacts}} Whereas the Double Irish and Single Malt BEPS tools enable Ireland to act as a ''confidential'' "[[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFC]]" for rerouting untaxed profits to places like Bermuda (e.g. it must be ''confidential'' as higher-tax locations would not sign full tax treaties with locations like Bermuda), the CAIA BEPS tool, enables Ireland to act as the "[[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFC]]" (e.g. the terminus for untaxed profits, like Bermuda). {{quote box |width=19em|border=1px|align=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|qalign=left |quote =I cannot see a justification for giving large amounts of Irish [corporate] tax relief to the intragroup acquisition of a virtual [IP] group asset, except that it is for the purposes of facilitating [Irish] corporate tax avoidance. |salign=left |source=Professor Jim Stewart, [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]]
"MNE Tax Strategies in Ireland" (2016){{Cite web|title=MNE Tax Strategies in Ireland|url=https://www.tcd.ie/business/assets/pdf/MNE-tax-strategies-and-ireland.pdf|publisher=[[Trinity College Dublin]]|author1=Adjunct Professor Jim Stewart|date=2016}}}} CAIA uses the accepted tax concept of providing [[capital allowance]]s for the purchase of physical assets.{{efn|Most tax codes in developed countries have [[capital allowance]] programs that give tax relief on capital expenditure that is amortised over the life of the physical asset on which the capital was invested in.}} However, Ireland turns it into a BEPS tool by providing the allowances for the purchase of ''[[intangible assets]]'', and particularly ''[[intellectual property]]'' assets; and critically, where the owner of the intangible assets is a "connected party" (e.g. a Group subsidiary, often located in a tax haven); and has valued the assets for the inter-Group transaction using an Irish [[International Financial Services Centre|IFSC]] accounting firm. CAIA ''capitalises'' the tax shield of the Double Irish, and thus materially increases the distortion of the Irish national accounts. This was shown in July 2016 when the Irish CEO had to restate Irish 2015 GDP by 34.4% due to Apple's Q1 2015 "[[leprechaun economics]]" restructure into a CAIA BEPS tool.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/world/apple-taxes-jersey.html|title=After a Tax Crackdown, Apple Found a New Shelter for Its Profits|publisher=New York Times|author=Jesse Drucker|author2=Simon Bowers|date=6 November 2017}} A June 2018 report by the EU Parliament's [[European United Left-Nordic Green Left|GUE–NGL]] body showed that Apple doubled the Irish corporate tax shield of its CAIA BEPS tool by financing the acquisition of the IP via Jersey (the report called the CAIA BEPS tool, the ''[[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]]'').{{cite web|url= https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/06/25/new-report-is-apple-paying-less-than-1-tax-in-the-eu/|title=New Report on Apple's New Irish Tax Structure|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|author=Naomi Fowler|date=25 June 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://src.bna.com/zNy|title=Apple's Irish Tax Deals|publisher=[[European United Left-Nordic Green Left]] EU Parliament|author1=Martin Brehm Christensen|author2=Emma Clancy|date=21 June 2018}} Whereas the Double Irish and Single Malt have an ETR of less than 1%, the ETR of the CAIA BEPS tool ranges from 0% to 3% depending on the date on which the CAIA tool was started (see [[#Effective tax rate (ETR)|effective tax rates]]).{{efn|name="cap"}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mhc.ie/latest/e-zines/world-ip-day-2014/P1|title=World IP Day: IRELAND'S 2.5% IP Tax Rate (Section 4.1.1)|publisher=Mason Hayes and Curran (Law Firm)|date=April 2013|quote=When combined with other features of Ireland’s IP tax regime, an effective rate as low as 2.5% can be achieved on IP related income}} ====Knowledge Development Box==== Ireland created the first OECD–compliant '''Knowledge Development Box''' ("KDB"), in the 2015 ''Finance Act'', to further support it's [[intellectual property]] [[base erosion and profit shifting|BEPS]] toolkit.{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.ie/business/budget/budget-2016-do-you-know-what-the-knowledge-box-is-31576795.html|title=Do you know what the Knowledge Box is?|publisher=Irish Indepdendant|date=9 October 2015|author=Michael Cogley|quote=The initial announcement of the KDB came after the closure of the ‘double Irish’ tax loophole and while he does not see it as a knee-jerk reaction Ken Hardy, tax partner at KPMG believes it is an attempt to keep Ireland’s tax scheme as competitive as possible. However, other European countries, including Germany, have warned that these incentives should only be used as a reward for R&D investment and not as a tax avoidance to}} The KDB behaves like a [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|CAIA]] BEPS scheme with a cap of 50% (i.e. similar to getting 50%–relief against capitalised IP, for a net effective Irish tax rate of 6.25%). As with the CAIA BEPS scheme, the KDB is limited to specific "qualifying assets", however, unlike CAIA tool, these are quite narrowly defined by the 2015 ''Finance Act''.{{cite web|url = https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-29/29-03-01.pdf|title=Revenue Guidance Notes for Knowledge Development Box|publisher=Revenue Commissioners|date=2016}}{{cite web|url = http://www.bdo.ie/en-gb/insights/tax/knowledge-development-box/knowledge-development-box-(kdb)|title=Guidelines Knowledge Development Box|publisher=BDO Ireland|date=2016}} The Irish KDB was created with tight conditions to ensure OECD compliance and thus meets the OECD's "modified Nexus standard" for IP.{{cite web| url = https://www.oecd.org/ctp/beps-action-5-agreement-on-modified-nexus-approach-for-ip-regimes.pdf|title=Action 5 Agreement on Modified Nexus Approach for IP Regimes|publisher=OECD|date=2015}} This has drawn criticism from Irish tax advisory firms who feel that its use is limited to pharmaceutical (who have the most "Nexus" compliant patents/processes), and some niche sectors.{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/ie/en/pages/tax/articles/knowledge-development-box-ireland.html|title=Knowledge Development Box Improvements Needed|publisher=Deloitte Ireland|date=2016}}{{cite web|url=https://home.kpmg.com/ie/en/home/insights/2016/04/kdb-best-in-class.html|title=Knowledge Development Box: Best in Class?|publisher=KPMG Ireland|date=16 April 2016}} It is expected these conditions will be relaxed over time through refinements of the 2015 ''Finance Act''; a route taken by other Irish [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS]] tools: * [[Double Irish]] – the unusual definition of tax residence was embedded in the 1997 ''Taxes and Consolidation Act'' (TCA), and expanded in 1999-2003 ''Finance Acts''.{{cite web|url=https://www.revenue.ie/en/tax-professionals/tdm/income-tax-capital-gains-tax-corporation-tax/part-02/02-02-03.pdf|title=Guidance on Tax Residence Irish Revenue|publisher=Revenue Commissioners|date=2017}} * [[Double Irish arrangement#Single malt|Single Malt]] – takes the Double Irish tax-residence concept around "management and control", and worded directly into specific bilateral tax treaties (Malta, UAE). * [[Double Irish arrangement#CAIA|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]] – introduced in the 1997 TCA but expanded in the 2009 ''Finance Act'', and made tax-free in the 2015 ''Finance Act'' for Apple.{{efn|name="cap"}} * [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110 SPVs]] – created in the 1997 TCA with strong anti-avoidance controls, which were eroded in 2003, 2008, 2011 ''Finance Acts'' (see [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)|Section 110]] article). * [[L–QIAIFs]] – [[QIAIF]]s were introduced in 2013 with the new EU [[Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive 2011|AIFMD]] regulations, but expanded in 2018 into a full [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tool]]. Irish tax-law firms expect the Irish KDB terms will be brought into alignment with the CAIA BEPS tool terms in the future.{{cite web|url=https://www.matheson.com/images/uploads/documents/KDB_Matheson.pdf|title=Knowledge Development Box Public Consultation and Observations|publisher=Matheson|date=April 2015}} ===Debt–based BEPS tools=== ====Section 110 SPV==== {{main article|Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)}} [[File:Stephen Donnelly 2016.jpg|thumb|'''[[Stephen Donnelly|Stephen Donnelly TD]]''' Estimated U.S. funds would avoid €20 billion in Irish taxes from 2016–2026 on circa €40 billion of Irish investments (2012–2016), by using Section 110 SPVs.{{cite web|url=http://stephendonnelly.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Closing-Down-Section-110-for-Vulture-Funds.pdf | title=WHY LETTING SECTION 110 SPVS OPERATE IN THE IRISH DOMESTIC ECONOMY WILL DAMAGE OUR TAX BASE AND OUR REPUTATION AS A ‘LOW-TAX’ ECONOMY | publisher=Stephen Donnelly (Dail Submission)|date=September 2016}}]] A '''Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle''' ("SPV") is an Irish [[tax resident]] company, which qualifies under Section 110 of the 1997 ''Irish Taxes Consolidation Act'' (“TCA”), by virtue of restricting itself to only holding "qualifying assets", for a special tax regime that enables the SPV to attain full tax neutrality (i.e. the SPV pays no Irish corporate taxes). It is a major Irish [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS]] tool. Section 110 was created to help [[International Financial Services Centre]] ("IFSC") legal and accounting firms compete for the administration of global [[securitisation]] deals. While they pay no Irish taxes, they contribute circa €100 million annually to the Irish economy from fees paid to the IFSC legal and accounting firms.{{cite web|url=http://www.idsa.ie/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/IDSA_Securitisation-Industry-in-Ireland.pdf|title=Ireland: The Leading European Jurisdiction for SPVs, Structured Finance and Securitised Structures|publisher=Irish Debt Securities Association|date=2016}} IFSC firms lobbied the Irish State for [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Evolution|successive amendments]] to the Section 110 legislation, so that by 2011, Section 110 had become an Irish Debt–based BEPS tool, for avoiding tax on Irish and international assets. In 2016, it was discovered that U.S. distressed debt funds used Section 110 SPVs, structured by IFSC professional service firms,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/how-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Fcommercial-property%2Fhow-do-vulture-funds-exploit-tax-loopholes-1.2832688| title=How do vulture funds exploit tax loopholes?| publisher=Irish Times|date=17 October 2016}} to avoid material Irish taxes{{cite web|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/news/speedy-probe-into-vulture-funds-tax-urged-326329|title=Speedy probe into vulture funds' tax urged|publisher=Sunday Business Post|date=25 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/stephen-donnelly-tax-avoidance-anomaly-means-pain-for-taxpayers-34906487.html|title=Tax avoidance could run to billions|publisher=Irish Independent|date=24 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/eagles-potential-loss-bigger-than-190m-35076379.html|title=Project Eagle's potential loss bigger than £190m|publisher=Irish Independent|date=25 September 2016}} on domestic Irish activities, {{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/vultures-minimise-their-tax-bills-as-state-now-appears-to-have-delivered-the-sale-of-the-century-34981270.html|title='Vultures' minimise their tax bills - as State now appears to have delivered the sale of the century|publisher=Irish Independent|date=21 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.davidmcwilliams.ie/vulture-funds-rub-salt-into-the-carcass-of-this-country/|title=Vulture funds rub salt into the carcass of this country|publisher=David McWilliams Sunday Business Post|date=1 August 2016}} while State-backed mezzanine funds were using Section 110 SPVs to lower their clients Irish corporate tax liability.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/seen-heard-state-backed-funds-using-section-110-to-slash-tax-bill-1.3141025|title=State-backed funds using Section 110 to slash tax bill|publisher=Irish Times|date=2 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/cardinal-capital-warns-of-damage-by-new-s110-35038346.html|title=Cardinal Capital warns of 'damage' by new S110 Rules=Irish Times|date=11 September 2016}} Academic studies in 2017 note that Irish Section 110 SPVs operate in a [[brass plate company|brass plate]] fashion{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/imf-queries-lawyers-and-bankers-on-hundreds-of-ifsc-boards-1.2811754|title=IMF queries lawyers and bankers on hundreds of IFSC boards|publisher=The Irish Times|date=30 September 2016}} with little regulatory oversight from the Irish Revenue or Central Bank of Ireland,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/a-third-of-ireland-s-shadow-banking-subject-to-little-or-no-oversight-1.3077931?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fa-third-of-ireland-s-shadow-banking-subject-to-little-or-no-oversight-1.3077931|title=A web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/former-regulator-says-irish-politicians-mindless-over-ifsc-russian-risks-1.3414779?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fformer-regulator-says-irish-politicians-mindless-over-ifsc-russian-risks-1.3414779|title=Former Regulator says Irish politicians mindless of IFSC risks|publisher=The Irish Times|date=5 March 2018}} and have been attracting funds from undesirable activities (e.g. [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses|sanctioned Russian banks]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.tasc.ie/download/pdf/seminar_on_section_110_12th_jan_2017.pdf|title=‘Section 110’ Companies: A Success story for Ireland|publisher=Professor Jim Stewart Cillian Doyle| date=12 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tasc.ie/download/pdf/ireland_global_finance_and_the_russian_connection.pdf|title=Ireland, Global Finance and the Russian Connection|publisher=Professor Jim Stewart Cillian Doyle| date=27 February 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/russian-bank-collapse-shines-light-into-shadowy-corners-of-irish-finance-34482531.html|title=Russian bank collapse shines light into shadowy corners of Irish finance|publisher=Irish Independent|date=25 February 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/news/russian-firms-funnelled-e100bn-dublin-410840|title=How Russian Firms Funnelled €100bn through Dublin|publisher=The Sunday Business Post|date=4 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/media-and-marketing/more-than-100bn-in-russian-money-funnelled-though-dublin-1.3414480|title=More than €100bn in Russian Money funneled through Dublin|publisher=The Irish Times|date=4 March 2018}} These [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses|abuses]] were discovered because Section 110 SPVs must file public accounts with the Irish [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]]. In 2018 [[Central Bank of Ireland]] overhauled the little-used [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)#L-QIAIF|L–QIAIF]] vehicle, so that is now offers the same tax benefits on Irish assets held via debt as the Section 110 SPV, but without having to file Irish public accounts. ====L–QIAIF==== {{main|Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)}} [[File:Dublin Office sales price, as a multiple of cost of build, versus EU-28 (2016).jpg|thumb|Sales price as multiple of the cost of build for a prime office in Dublin, versus other EU-28 countries (2016).]] [[File:Dublin Office sales price versus EU-28 (2016).jpg|thumb|Sales price of Dublin prime office versus other EU-28 countries (2016).]] The Irish [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)|QIAIF]] regime is exempt from all Irish taxes and duties (including VAT and withholding tax), and apart from the VCC wrapper, do not have to file public accounts with the Irish [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]]. This has made [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)|QIAIF]] an important "backdoor" out of the Irish corporate tax system. The most favoured destination is to [[Conduit and Sink OFCs|Sink OFC]] Luxembourg, which receives 50% of all outbound Irish [[foreign direct investment]] ("FDI).{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2018/06/28/Ireland-Selected-Issues-46027|page=20|quote=Figure 3. Foreign Direct Investment - Over half of Irish outbound FDI is routed to Luxembourg|title=Ireland:Selected Issues|publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]]|date=June 2018}} QIAIFs, with Section 110 SPVs, have made Ireland the 3rd largest [[Offshore financial centre#Shadow banking|Shadow Banking OFC]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/irish/ireland-has-worlds-fourth-largest-shadow-banking-sector-hosting-202-trillion-of-assets-35701058.html|title=Ireland has world's fourth-largest shadow banking sector, hosting €2.02 trillion of assets|publisher=Irish Independent|date=18 March 2018}} When the Section 110 SPV Irish domestic tax avoidance [[Irish Section 110 Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV)#Abuses|scandals]] surfaced in late 2016, it was due to Irish financial journalists and [[Dail Eireann]] representatives scrutinising the Irish [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]] public accounts of U.S. distressed firms. In November 2016 the [[Central Bank of Ireland|Central Bank]] began to overhaul the [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)#L-QIAIF rationale|L-QIAIF]] regime. In early 2018, the Central Bank upgraded the [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)#L-QIAIF rationale|L-QIAIF]] regime so that it could replicate the Section 110 SPV (e.g. closed end debt structures), but without needing to file public [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]] accounts. In June 2018, the Central Bank announced that €55 billion of U.S. distressed debt assets had transferred out of Section 110 SPVs.{{cite web|url= https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/tax-free-funds-once-favoured-by-vultures-fall-55bn-1.3546101|title=Tax-free funds once favoured by ‘vultures’ fall €55bn: Regulator attributes decline to the decision of funds to exit their so-called ‘section 110 status’|publisher=Irish Times|date=28 June 2018}} It is expected that the Irish [[Qualifying investor alternative investment fund (QIAIF)#L-QIAIF rationale|L–QIAIF]] will replace the Irish Section 110 SPV as Ireland's main [[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tool]] for U.S. multinationals in Ireland. The ability of foreign institutions to use QIAIFs (and particularly the ICAV wrapper) to avoid all Irish taxes on Irish assets has been blamed for the bubble in Dublin commercial property (and, by implication, the Dublin housing crisis).{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/tax-breaks-for-commercial-property-will-fuel-bubble-35189754.html| title=Tax breaks for commercial property will fuel bubble| quote=They'll do this by making commercial property investment, mainly by large foreign landlords, entirely tax free. This will drive up commercial rents, suppress residential development, put Irish banks at risk, and deprive the State of much-needed funds.|publisher=Irish Independent|date=6 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://stephendonnelly.ie/finance-bill-could-turn-commercial-property-bubble-into-next-crash/| title=Finance Bill Could Turn Commercial Property Bubble into next Crash| publisher=[[Stephen Donnelly]] T.D.|date=6 November 2016}} This risk was highlighted in 2014 when [[Central Bank of Ireland]] consulted the [[European Systemic Risk Board]] ("ESRB") after lobbying to expand the L-QIAIF regime.{{cite web|url=https://docplayer.net/31887836-Loan-origination-qiaifs-central-bank-consults.html| title=Loan Origination QIAIFs-Central Bank Consults| quote=ESRB: Nonetheless, if not subject to adequate macro- and micro-prudential regulation, this activity could grow rapidly and introduce new sources of financial stability risk. It could also raise the financial system’s vulnerability to runs, contagion, excessive credit growth and pro-cyclicality.|publisher=Dillon Eustace Law Firm|date=14 July 2014}} ===TP–based BEPS tools=== Ireland's [[transfer pricing]] ("TP") based BEPS tools are mostly related to [[contract manufacturing]]. By refusing to implement the 2013 EU Accounting Directive (and invoking exemptions on reporting holding company structures until 2022), Ireland enables their TP and IP–based BEPS tools to structure as "unlimited liability companies" (ULCs) which do not have to file public accounts with the Irish [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]].{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/06/25/new-report-is-apple-paying-less-than-1-tax-in-the-eu/|title=New report: is Apple paying less than 1% tax in the EU?|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=28 June 2018|quote=The use of private "unlimited liability company" (ULC) status, which exempts companies from filing financial reports publicly. The fact that Apple, Google, and many others continue to keep their Irish financial information secret is due to a failure by the Irish government to implement the 2013 EU Accounting Directive, which would require full public financial statements, until 2017, and even then retaining an exemption from financial reporting for certain holding companies until 2022}}{{cite web|url=http://www.taxresearch.org.uk/Blog/2018/07/04/irelands-playing-games-in-the-last-chance-saloon-of-tax-justice/|title=Ireland's playing games in the last chance saloon of tax justice|publisher=[[Richard Murphy (tax campaigner)|Richard Murphy]]|date=4 July 2018|quote=Local subsidiaries of multinationals must always be required to file their accounts on public record, which is not the case at present. Ireland is not just a tax haven at present, it is also a corporate secrecy jurisdiction.}} In spite of this, many Irish IP–based BEPS tools are so large that tax academics have been able to separate out their scale from filed group accounts (e.g. work of [[Gabriel Zucman]]). However, Irish TP–based BEPS tools are smaller, and therefore harder to pick out from a listed multinational's group accounts. In addition, the Irish State, to help obfuscate the activities of the larger and more important IP–based BEPS tools, sometimes present their data as ''manufacturing'' data, and blended in with TP–based BEPS data; the example of how the Irish State [[Leprechaun economics#Obfuscation of source|obfuscated]] Apple's Q1 2015 CAIA BEPS tool, by crediting the 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] GDP growth rate to contract manufacturing and aircraft leasing activities is a notable case. It is generally regarded that Ireland's main TP–based BEPS tool users are the life sciences manufacturers. =={{anchor|ETR}}Effective tax rate (ETR)== ===Background=== The ''headline'' tax rate is the rate of taxation that is applied to the profits that a tax-code deems to be taxable after deductions. The ''effective'' tax rate is the rate of taxation implied by the actual quantum of tax paid versus profits before all deductions are applied. The gap between the Irish corporate ''headline'' rate of 12.5%, and the much lower Irish corporate ''effective'' rate of 2–4%, is a source of controversy: {{quote|Many of the multinationals gathered at the Four Seasons [in Dublin, Ireland] that day pay far less than 12.5 percent tax, their accounts show. Ireland helps them do this by generously defining what profit it will tax, and what it will leave untouched.|source=Holly Ellyatt, [[CNBC]], "In Europe's Tax Race, It's the Base, Not the Rate, That Counts", 18 February 2013{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/100467344|title=In Europe's Tax Race, It's the Base, Not the Rate, That Counts|author=Holly Ellyatt||publisher=CNBC|date=18 February 2013}}}} {{quote|Applying a 12.5% rate in a tax code that shields most corporate profits from taxation, is indistinguishable from applying a near 0% rate in a normal tax code.|source=[[Jonathan Weil]], [[Bloomberg View]], 11 February 2014{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2014-02-11/weil-on-finance-yes-ireland-is-a-tax-haven|title=Weil on Finance: Yes, Ireland Is a Tax Haven|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|author=[[Jonathan Weil]]|date=11 February 2014}}}} {{quote|Apple isn’t in Ireland primarily for Ireland’s 12.5 percent corporate tax rate. The goal of many U.S. multinational firms’ tax planning is globally untaxed profits, or something close to it. And Apple, it turns out, doesn’t pay that much tax in Ireland.|source=[[Brad Setser]], [[Council on Foreign Relations]], 30 October 2017{{Cite web|title=Apple’s Exports Aren’t Missing: They Are in Ireland|url = https://www.cfr.org/blog/apples-exports-arent-missing-they-are-ireland|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|author=[[Brad Setser]]|date=30 October 2017}}}} The Irish State asserts Ireland's ETR similar to the Irish ''headline'' CT rate of 12.5%.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2014/02/11/irish-pm-counters-corporate-tax-rate-claims-.html|title=Irish PM counters corporate tax rate claims|publisher=[[CNBC]]|date=February 2014}} This is an important issue as Ireland's BEPS tools, the core of Ireland's {{slink|#Low tax economy}}, rely on having a global network of full bilateral tax treaties that accept Ireland's BEPS tools; major economies do not sign full bilateral tax treaties with known tax havens (e.g. Bermuda or Jersey).{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/taxanalysts/2013/11/06/if-ireland-is-not-a-tax-haven-what-is-it/#79ff76d37746|title=If Ireland Is Not A Tax Haven, What Is It?|publisher=[[Forbes Magazine]]||author=Martin Sullivan|date=November 2014|quote=They cannot have their regional headquarters located in a jurisdiction that--whether fairly or unfairly--has obtained a reputation for less-than-aboveboard business dealings. The label "tax haven" implies sunny beaches and shady business. If Ireland wants to continue to attract investment by the world's most respected companies, it desperately needs to avoid the tax haven label.}} When the EU Commission published their findings on Apple's Irish BEPS tools in 2016 (see below), Brazil became the first G–20 economy to blacklist Ireland as a tax haven, and suspended the Brazil–Ireland bilateral tax treaty.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ireland-brazil-funds/blacklisted-by-brazil-dublin-funds-find-new-ways-to-invest-idUSL8N1MK2NX|title=Blacklisted by Brazil, Dublin funds find new ways to invest|publisher=Reuters|date=20 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/04/10/tax-haven-blacklisting-13-latin-american-countries/|title=Tax haven blacklisting in Latin America|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=6 April 2017}} In 2014, Ireland refused to implement the 2013 EU Accounting Directive, and invoked exemptions on reporting holding company structures until 2022, so that multinationals can register as Irish "unlimited liability companies" (ULCs), which do not have to file public accounts with the Irish [[Companies Registration Office (Ireland)|CRO]]. However, as most foreign multinationals in Ireland are major U.S. listed companies (see ''[[#Table 1|Table 1]]''), tax academics have been able to estimate their Irish ETR from U.S. filings. In addition, the 2014–2016 EU investigation into Apple, Ireland's largest company, produced detail on Apple's Irish ETR from 2004–2014. {{quote|Make no mistake: the ''headline'' rate is not what triggers tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. That comes from schemes that facilitate ''profit shifting''.|source=[[Pierre Moscovici]], [[Financial Times]], 11 March 2018{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2b356956-17fc-11e8-9376-4a6390addb44|title=Multinationals pay lower taxes than a decade ago|publisher=Financial Times|date=11 March 2018}}}} ===Independent research=== In February 1994, the most cited academic in tax haven research,{{cite web|url=https://ideas.repec.org/cgi-bin/htsearch?form=extended&wm=wrd&dt=range&ul=&q=tax+haven&cmd=Search%21&wf=4BFF&s=C&db=&de=|title=IDEAS/RePEc Database|quote=Tax Havens by Most Cited}} American tax economist [[James R. Hines Jr.]], published the most cited academic paper on tax havens, titled: "Fiscal Paradise: Foreign Tax Havens and American Business"; which estimated in Appendix IV that Ireland's ''aggregate'' effective corporate rate (ETR) was 4%. In October 2013, Bloomberg commissioned a ''Special Investigation'' into the tax affairs of U.S. multinationals in Ireland, which estimated that the effective tax rate of all U.S. multinationals in Ireland had fallen to 3% by 2010.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/infographics/u-s-profits-in-ireland-pile-up.html|title=Ireland: Where Profits Pile Up, Helping Multinationals Keep Taxes Low|publisher=Bloomberg News|quote=Meanwhile, the tax rate reported by those Irish subsidiaries of U.S. companies plummeted to 3% from 9% by 2010|date=October 2013}} The report featured research into the "architect" of the Double Irish BEPS tool, PWC tax partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]], who Bloomberg noted was regarded as a "hero" in Ireland. In February 2014, [[Trinity College, Dublin]] Professor of Finance, Dr. Jim Stewart, author of studies into Ireland's tax systems,{{cite web |url=https://www.tasc.ie/download/pdf/apple_tax_case.pdf|title=Apple Tax Case and the Implications for Ireland|page=19|author=Professor Jim Stewart|publisher=[[Trinity College, Dublin]]|quote=It is important to note that the most attractive aspect of [corporate] tax incentives offered by Ireland is not the [headline 12.5%] tax rate but the tax regime|date=28 June 2017}} used the U.S. [[Bureau of Economic Analysis]] data filed by U.S. multinationals on their global operations, to estimate that the effective tax rate of U.S. multinationals in Ireland for 2011 was 2.2% to 3.8% (depending on assumptions).{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/corporate-tax-calculations-1.1689233?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fcorporate-tax-calculations-1.1689233|quote=A study by Dr Jim Stewart, associate professor in finance at Trinity College Dublin, suggests that in 2011 the subsidiaries of U.S. multinationals in Ireland paid an effective tax rate of 2.2 per cent. |title=Effective Corporate Tax calculations: 2.2%|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=14 February 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/multinationals-escape-tax-due-to-exceptional-rules-study-claims-1.1784447|title=Multinationals escape tax due to ‘exceptional’ rules, study claims|publisher=Irish Times|date=6 May 2014}} In November 2014, the ''[[Tax Justice Network]]'', in their ''Ireland Country Report'' from the 2013 [[Financial Secrecy Index]], said the Irish State's claims that the effective tax rate was 12.5% were "misleading", and that Ireland's corporate ETR was between 2.5% to 4.5%, depending on the various assumptions used.{{cite web|url=https://www.financialsecrecyindex.com/Archive2013/Country%20Reports/Ireland.pdf|title=TAX JUSTICE NETWORK: Ireland Financial Secrecy Index Country Report 2014|quote=Misleadingly, studies cited employees' and no exports: it is entirely inapplicable to transnationals. Though there are various ways to calculate effective tax rates, other studies find rates of just 2.5–4.5 percent.|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=November 2014}} In November 2017, Irish economist [[David McWilliams (economist)|David McWilliams]] writing in the ''[[Irish Times]]'' quoted that the U.S. BEA statistics implied that U.S. multinationals in Ireland paid an effective tax rate of 3.27% on Irish registered pre-tax income of $106,789 million in 2013, and 3.38% on Irish registered pre-tax income of $108,971 million in 2014, due to "a myriad of loopholes to avoid even our own low rates of tax".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/david-mcwilliams-a-new-economic-plan-for-ireland-1.3294430|title=A new economic plan for Ireland|date=18 November 2017|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=[[David McWilliams (economist)|David McWilliams]]|quote=Our corporation tax rate is 12.5 per cent, so they should be paying about €12 billion a year in tax. But they paid only €3.25 billion. This means that about almost €9 billion is missing because these companies use a myriad of loopholes to avoid even our low rates of tax.}} In June 2018, 24 years after the 1994 James R. Hines paper into global corporate tax havens, noted French tax economist [[Gabriel Zucman]], in his major study into the BEPS flows of global tax havens titled: "The Missing Profits of Nations";{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=Such profit shifting leads to a total annual revenue loss of $200 billion globally|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}} also estimated in Appendix I of the study that Ireland's ''aggregate'' effective corporate tax rate was 4%.{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/|title=APPENDIX 1 Table 2 : The Missing Profits of Nations|page=31|quote=Ireland's effective tax rate on all foreign corporates (U.S. and non–U.S.) is 4%|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Torslov|author3=Ludvig Wier|date=June 2018}} ===Filed accounts=== Over the years, the largest U.S. multinationals in Ireland, who are both Ireland's largest companies and pay most of Ireland's corporation tax (see [[#Low tax economy|low tax economy]]), have filed various accounts showing their Irish ETR. As discussed above, because Ireland refused to ratify the 2013 EU Accounting Directive, many of these multinationals have switched to "unlimited liability companies" in Ireland, which do not file accounts; thus the information is only available in a few cases. However, where U.S. multinationals have disclosed Irish financials, they all imply an Irish ETR of less than 1 percent.{{efn|Note that the accounts referenced below are from U.S. multinationals in Apple has been in Ireland since at least December 1980, when it opened its first Irish plant in Holyhill, in Cork. Apple's tax strategies with Irish BEPS tools had long been under suspicion by tax academics and investigative journalists.{{Cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08853908.2017.1356250|title=The Rotten Apple: Tax Avoidance in Ireland|journal=The International Trade Journal|volume=32|pages=150|date=2 news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2013/0531/453905-ambassador-us-tax/|title=US Senator repeats Irish 'tax haven' claim|last=|first=|date=31 May 2013|work=|newspaper=RTE.ie|access-date=14 web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/the-holy-grail-of-tax-avoidance-schemes-was-made-in-the-us-1.1878617|title=The 'Holy Grail of tax avoidance schemes' was made in the US|publisher=Irish Times|quote=|date=26 July 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/ireland-is-apples-holy-grail-of-tax-avoidance-918345-May2013/|title=Ireland is Apple's 'Holy Grail of tax avoidance': The firm pays just two per cent tax on profits in Ireland but has denied using any "tax gimmicks".|publisher=journal.ie|quote=|date=23 May 2013}} In June 2014, the EU Commission launched an investigation into Apple's tax practices in Ireland for the period 2004–2014, whose summary findings were published on 30 August 2016 in a 4–page [[press release]]; with a 130–page report, including partially redacted information on Apple's Irish business (e.g. profits, employees, Board minutes etc.), published on 30 August 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/apple-s-irish-company-structure-key-to-eu-tax-finding-1.2775684|title=Apple’s Irish company structure key to EU tax selective treatment allowed Apple to pay an effective corporate tax rate of 1 per cent on its European profits in 2003, down to 0.005 per cent in 2014". ===Irish State rebuttals=== In February 2014, as a result of Bloomberg's ''Special Investigation'' and Trinity College Professor Dr. Jim Stewart's ETR calculations (see above), the "architect" of Ireland's Double Irish BEPS tool, PricewaterhouseCoopers tax-partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]], went on ''[[RTE Radio]]'' to state that: "there was a hole the size of the Grand Canyon", in the analysis.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/multinationals-paid-2-2-per-cent-tax-1310050-Feb2014/|title=Multinational companies paid just 2.2 per cent tax in 2011 - report|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|date=15 February 2014|author=Paul Hosford|quote=[Dr. Stewart] criticised the report’s use of a single company for a host of countries across the world, telling RTÉ’s Morning Ireland that the PWC report was based on a “fictitious or hypothetical” company, adding: You can’t say we have an effective tax rate of 11.9 per cent. Fergal O’Rourke from PWC, however, defended his company’s findings, saying that Stewart was counting companies incorporated in Ireland, but that had never operated here. “There’s a hole the size of the Grand Canyon in the data.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1027229.shtml|title=Corporate Tax 2014: Feargal O'Rourke's Irish tax fairytales and "meaningless" US data|publisher=Finfacts|date=14 February 2014}} O'Rourke also referenced the PricewaterhouseCoopers/World Bank survey that Ireland's ETR was circa 12%.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d9b4fd34-ca3f-11e3-8a31-00144feabdc0|title=Tax avoidance: The Irish inversion|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=29 April 2014|author1=Vanessa Houlder|author2=Vincent Boland|author3=James Politi|quote=Call it the ceramic flower pot dilemma. The headline rate of Irish corporation tax is 12.5 per cent, and calculations by PwC and the World Bank show the effective rate of tax levied on foreign company profits in Ireland is about 11.9 per cent. Yet a recent study by Jim Stewart, associate professor of finance at Trinity College Dublin, shows some US multinational subsidiaries operating in Ireland paid an effective rate of tax of just 2.2 per cent on their Irish activities in 2011. Prof Stewart argued that, in order for PwC and the World Bank to compare tax rates across the world, they created a hypothetical company that does not engage in tax planning, and was “small, domestically owned, has no imports or exports and produces and sells ceramic flower pots”. Such a company bears no resemblance to the US multinationals that operate in Ireland, ranging from big pharma (Pfizer, Alexion) to big tech (Intel, Google, Apple, Facebook).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.budget.gov.ie/Budgets/2015/Documents/Technical_Paper_Effective_Rates_Corporation_Tax_Ireland.pdf|title=Effective Corporate Tax in Ireland: April 2014|publisher=Department of Finance|date=April 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/cantillon-transparency-the-first-victim-in-tax-debate-1.1695254|title=Cantillon: Transparency the first victim in tax debate|publisher=Irish Times|date=18 February 2014}} In December 2014, the Irish [[Department of Finance (Ireland)|Department of Finance]], gathered a panel of Irish experts (but no international experts) to estimate Irish corporate ETR for the Committee on Finance Public Expenditure. The results, summarised on Section 2 (page 13) of the report, showed all of the Irish experts, with the exception of Dr. Jim Stewart, agreed with Feargal O'Rourke and PricewaterhouseCoopers: * 11.1% Prof. Frank Barry [[Trinity College, Dublin]] (using Devereaux methodology) * 14.4% Mr. Gary Tobin [[Department of Finance]] (using European Commission/ZEW data) * 12.5% Mr. Eamonn O’Dea [[Revenue Commissioners]] (using Irish [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]] Statistical Data) * 12.4% Mr. Conor O’Brien [[KPMG]] (Ireland) (using Irish [[Revenue Commissioners|Revenue]] Statistical Data) * 2.2% to 3.8% Prof. Jim Stewart [[Trinity College, Dublin]] (using U.S. [[Bureau of Economic Analysis|BEA]] Data) In August 2016, when the EU Commission published the results of their 2–year detailed investigation of Apple's tax structure in Ireland (see above), showing that Apple's ETR in 2014 was 0.005%,{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-16-2923_en.htm|title=State aid: Ireland gave illegal tax benefits to Apple worth up to €13 billion|publisher=EU Commission|date=30 August 2016}} the Irish [[Revenue Commissioners]] stated that they: "had collected the full amount of tax that was due from Apple in accordance with the Irish law".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/revenue-insists-it-collected-all-taxes-apple-owed-1.2772934?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ftechnology%2Frevenue-insists-it-collected-all-taxes-apple-owed-1.2772934|title=Revenue commissioned on the Irish corporate tax code by [[University College Cork|UCC]] economist, Seamus Coffey. The report estimated that Ireland's effective corporation tax rate for 2015 was 7.2%, based on the ''Net Operating Surplus Method'' (which accepts IP BEPS flows as tax deductible costs); and had fallen from 11.2% in 2008 (section 9.4 page 128). ==Corporate tax inversions== {{see also|Tax inversion}} ===Background=== An Irish '''[[corporate tax inversion]]''' is a strategy in which a foreign multinational acquires or merges with an Irish–based company, and then shifts its legal place of incorporation to Ireland to avail of Ireland's favourable corporate tax regime; however, the multinational's majority ownership, ''effective headquarters'' and executive management stay in its home jurisdiction.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/what-are-tax-inversions-1.2598741|title=What are tax inversions?|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|date=5 April 2016|quote=Inversions are in essence, a financial exercise which allow companies to lower their tax bills by acquiring a legal address abroad. This is typically done by acquiring a company in a country which levies a lower rate of corporation tax.}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-05-04/u-s-firms-with-irish-addresses-criticized-for-the-moves|title=Here’s How American CEOs Flee Taxes While Staying in U.S.|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|author=Zachary R. Mider|date=5 May 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/business/dealbook/ireland-us-tax-inversion.html?_r=0|title=Ireland, Home to U.S. ‘Inversions,’ Sees Huge Growth in G.D.P.|author=David Jolly|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=12 December 2016|quote=Under a typical inversion deal, a United States company takes over a foreign counterpart and, in the process, shifts its headquarters overseas. The takeover targets for such deals are typically based in countries with low corporate taxes — like Ireland, with its 12.5 percent rate.}} Ireland's corporate tax code has a holding company regime that enables the foreign multinational's new Irish–based ''legal headquarters'', to gain full Irish tax-relief on Irish withholding taxes and payment of dividends from Ireland.{{cite web|url=http://www.arthurcox.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/April2014_SpotlightOn.pdf|title=Structuring Tax Inversions to Ireland|publisher=Arthur Cox|author1=Ailish Finnerty|author2=Christopher McLaughlin|date=2014|quote=Currently, most inversions are structured as deal-related inversions rather than self-inversions because of the US anti-inversion rules in Section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code (US anti-inversion rules) (see below US Anti-inversion Rules).}} Almost all tax inversions to Ireland have come from the U.S., and to a lesser degree, the UK (see below); the first U.S. tax inversions to Ireland were [[Ingersoll Rand]] and [[Accenture]] 2009, and as of November 2018, Ireland was also the destination for the largest U.S. corporate tax inversion in history, namely the $81 billion merger of [[Medtronic]] and [[Covidien]] in 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestreet.com/slideshow/14222919/1/as-treasury-moves-to-bring-back-inversions-here-are-seven-of-the-biggest-recent-deals.html|title=As Treasury Moves to Bring Back Inversions, Here are 7 of the Biggest Recent Deals|author=Emily Stewart|date=22 July 2017|publisher=TheStreet}} The U.S. tax code's anti-avoidance rules prohibit a U.S. company simply creating a new "legal" headquarters in Ireland while its main business is in the US (known as a "self-inversion"). Up until April 2016, the U.S. tax code would only consider the inverted company as foreign (i.e. outside the U.S. tax-code), where the inversion was part of an acquisition, and the Irish target was at least 20% of the value of the combined group; although the Irish target had to be over 40% of the combined group for the inversion to be fully considered as outside of the U.S. tax-code.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/janetnovack/2014/09/10/the-tax-inversion-rush-in-one-handy-graphic/#4b2eac18bf02|title=The Tax Inversion Rush: One Handy Graphic|publisher=[[Forbes Magazine]]|author=Janet Novack|date=10 September 2014|quote=The U.S. company is in black, as is the share of the merged company its current shareholders will own; it must be less than 80% for the tax trick to work under the current law.}} Once inverted, the U.S. company can use Irish [[#Multinational tax schemes|multinational BEPS strategies]] to achieve an [[#ETR|effective tax rate]] well below the Irish headline rate of 12.5% on non–U.S. income, and also reduce U.S. taxes on U.S. income.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/quicktake/tax-inversion|title=Bloomberg Special TAX INVERSION|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2 May 2017}} In September 2014, ''[[Forbes Magazine]]'' quoted research that estimated a U.S. inversion to Ireland reduced the U.S. multinational's ''aggregate'' tax rate from above 30% to well below 20%. {{quote|''Intellectual Property'': The effective corporation tax rate can be reduced to as low as 2.5% for Irish companies whose trade involves the exploitation of intellectual property. The Irish IP regime is broad and applies to all types of IP. A generous scheme of capital allowances .... in Ireland offer significant incentives to companies who locate their activities in Ireland. A well-known global company [Accenture in 2009] recently moved the ownership and exploitation of an IP portfolio worth approximately $7 billion to Ireland.|source=Arthur Cox Law Firm,{{efn|name="law"}} "Uses of Ireland for German Companies" (January 2012)}} In July 2015, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' noted that Ireland's lower ETR made U.S. multinationals who inverted to Ireland highly acquisitive of other U.S. firms (i.e. they could afford to pay more to acquire U.S. competitors to re-domicile them to Ireland), and listed the post-inversion acquisitions of Activis/Allergan, Endo, Mallinckrodt and Horizon.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/horizon-pharma-at-the-nexus-of-taxes-and-deals-1436296946|publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|author=Liz Hoffman|date=7 July 2015|quote=Horizon and other inverted companies are using their new, lower tax rates to turbocharge corporate takeovers. Applying those rates, often in the midteens, to profits of companies in the U.S., with a federal corporate rate of 35%, can yield extra savings on top of those traditionally wrung from mergers. Moreover, unlike the U.S., Ireland and most other countries, only tax profits earned in-country, giving companies the freedom and incentive to shift income to still-lower-tax jurisdictions.|title=The Tax Inversion Wave Keeps Rolling}} In July 2017, the Irish [[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)|Central Statistics Office]] (CSO) warned that tax inversions to Ireland artificially inflated Ireland's GDP data (e.g. without providing any Irish tax revenue). {{quote|''Redomiciled PLCs in the Irish Balance of Payments'': Conducting little or no real activity in Ireland, these companies hold substantial investments overseas. By locating their headquarters in Ireland, the profits of these PLC’s are paid to them in Ireland, even though under double taxation agreements their tax liability arises in other jurisdictions. These profit inflows are retained in Ireland with a corresponding outflow only arising when a dividend is paid to the foreign owner.|[[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)]] (July 2017){{cite web|url = http://www.cso.ie/en/releasesandpublications/in/rpibp/redomiciledplcsintheirishbalanceofpayments/|title=Effect of Redomiciled PLCs|publisher=[[Central Statistics Office (Ireland)]]|date=July 2017}}}} ===U.S. inversions=== ====Share of inversions==== {{As of|November 2018}}, Bloomberg ranks Ireland as the most popular destination for U.S. tax inversions, attracting almost a quarter of the 85 inversions since 1982:{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/tax-inversion-tracker/|title=Tracking Tax Runaways|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=1 March 2017|quote=Bloomberg Special Reports: Corporate Tax Inversions}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |+ style="text-align: left;" |Destinations of U.S. Corporate Tax Inversions (1982–2018) |- !rowspan="2" style="text-align:left"|Destination !rowspan="2" style="text-align:right"|Total !colspan="2" style="text-align:left"|Last inversion !rowspan="2" style="text-align:right"|Notable U.S. corporate tax inversions to the destination |- !style="text-align:right"|Year !style="text-align:right"|Name |- |style="text-align:left"|Ireland||21||2016||[[Johnson Controls]]||Largest U.S. inversion in history, Medtronic (2015);
